name: Sample
description: This is a sample description

name: Kakagi Lake
description: The 32-unit Kakagi Lake property is host to the Penn Gold Occurrence where chip sampling has returned 12.75 g/t gold over 3.0 meters.  Drilling by Inco in a parallel zone (dubebd the Rainbow Zone) has intersected values up to 3.5 g/t gold over 4.7 meters.  Three other gold zones are on the property.
body:
Location and Access

The 32-unit Kakagi Lake property is located on a large peninsula on the north side of Kakagi Lake (locally called Crow Lake) 15 km north of Nestor Falls, Ontario. Nestor Falls is on the Kenora - Fort Frances Highway 71, approximately 120 km southeast of Kenora and 95 km northwest of Fort Frances, Ontario. Access is by motor boat from any of the commercial tourist camps on Kakagi Lake.  Alternatively, a float plane air base is located at Nestor Falls.  The Cameron Lake road, which trends eastward from Highway 71, 30 km north of Nestor Falls, leads to the Cameron Lake gold mine (20 km east of the highway).

Geology

The Kakagi Lake property lies within the western portion of the Wabigoon Subprovince of the Superior Province characterized by broad expanses of supracrustal rocks with synvolcanic, polyphase batholiths and minor gneissic units (Blackburn et al. 1991).  The area north of Kakagi Lake is transected by the Cameron Lake fault, a major regional northwest trending fault. A steeply dipping, east-west trending fault-shear zone is evident at the eastern end of Kakagi Lake. A major syncline occurs in the Emm Bay - Peninsula Bay area, while a major anticline occurs through the middle of the penninsula covering the Kakagi Lake property. 

The Kakagi Lake itself property covers an irregular gabbroic intrusion occurring within the mafic metavolcanics.  Most of the property is metamorphosed mafic and ultra mafic intrusive rocks. These range from gabbro to peridotite. Five small areas of felsic to intermediate meta volcanics and intercalated metasediments of dacite tuff, pyroclastic breccia and tuff breccia are mapped. Several felsite dikes were observed.  OGS Map 2447 indicates that the intrusive is layered and much more complex than previously interpreted, with numerous 'schist zones', shearing and carbonate alteration mapped.

Previous Work

The Kakagi-Rowan Lakes greenstone belt was the scene of significant gold exploration in the early 1900's. The first discoveries in the Kakagi-Rowan lakes area were gold occurrences at the western end of Sullivan Bay on Rowan Lake (Reliance, Monte Cristo, and Victor showings). These prospects were explored by adit, shallow shafts, trenching and diamond drilling by Lakeport Gold Mines Ltd. and the Victor Company. In addition, gold-bearing quartz veins (Martin-Kenty Prospect/Otonabee Mine) were discovered southwest of Flint Lake. 

Gold exploration activity increased in the area during the 1930's and 1940's as a result of an increase in the price of gold.  In May of 1945 Roy Martin and Leo Turcotte made a gold discovery in a carbonate zone on the peninsula in Kakagi Lake. When sampling the zone, a fair sized piece of free gold was noted.  

In 1974 Roy Martin and Jack Martin with Angus MacDonnell rediscovered the Martin-Turcotte Gold Showing and renamed it the 'A' Zone (later referred to as the 'Penn Gold Occurrence').  Reconnaissance led to the discovery of three more gold showings they called the B, C and D Zones.  Sampling by this syndicate group assayed as high as 0.41 oz. gold across 10 feet in the 'A' Zone and 10 feet of 0.14 oz. gold in the 'D' Zone.  The four gold zones are on the north limb of a major anticline.  The syndicate optioned the property to Welcome North Mines, who expanded upon the four zones located by the Syndicate, and uncovered a fifth zone they named the 'E' zone.

In 1985, Canadian Nickel (Inco) took an option on the property from Welcome North Mines (Penn Property).  Surface work by Inco included geophysical surveys, trenching, geological mapping and diamond drilling. 

Property Mineralization

The gold zones on the property are in altered carbonated gabbro intruded by quartz stringers and veins from 1/4" to 2 feet wide. In places the gabbro is slightly to intensely sheared. The quartz is mineralized with cube iron pyrite, magnetite and some chalcopyrite. Tourmaline was noted in some of the quartz. The contact of quartz with the altered gabbro is in places heavily mineralized for several inches into the gabbro.

'A' Zone

The 'A' zone represents the original discovery made by Martin and Turcotte in 1945.  It is a slightly sheared, carbonated, and altered gabbro with quartz stringers 1/4" to 8" wide and mineralized with pyrite and magnetite. The strike is east-west with a dip of 80° north.  On the eastern section of the zone, 60 feet of trenching has been blasted. Six chip samples each 10 feet long were taken across the trench. The best sample assayed 0.41 oz. gold across 10 feet.  Two trenches to the west of this trench assayed up to 0.02 oz/t gold.  Prospecting to the north, and adjoining this zone, indicated a 40 foot wide area 250 feet long with 'many good to very good pannings'.  A cedar swamp and low ground adjoins this area to the north.  The zone may be as much as 50-100 feet wide and has been traced along strike for 1,600 feet and is open to the west.  Approximately 2,000 feet west of this point, a zone of prominent shearing has been noted by Kaye (1981). It is possible that the anomaly could extend to this point.

'B' Zone

The 'B' zone is an outcrop 30 feet wide and 75 feet long 1,320 feet west and 200 feet south of the 'A' zone.  It is a carbonated, altered gabbro with quartz stringers and lenses 1/2" to 6" wide.  The strike of the zone is east-west. Some fair pannings have been noted from this zone. A 20 foot blasted rock trench assayed 0.02 oz/t gold.

'C' Zone

The 'C' zone is 700 feet south and 50 feet west of the 'B' Zone. It is a carbonated, altered gabbro with 1/2" to 4" wide quartz stringers mineralized with pyrite.  The strike is east-west with a dip of 80° north. The zone is 40 feet wide.  The centre of the zone is intensely sheared and pans fair tailings of gold. The south 15 feet of the zone is silicious with quartz stringers.  This was blasted and assayed trace gold across 15 ft.

'D' Zone

The 'D' zone is 130 feet southwest of the 'C' zone.  Rusty dirt along a 100 foot north-south area panned a little gold. A 110 foot trench was blasted along the zone.  The zone is a carbonated, altered gabbro with quartz stringers from 1/2" to 1 foot wide.  The strike of the zone varies from 60°- 75°with a dip of 80°N . At the north end of the trench it is slightly sheared for 20 feet then a further 65 feet which is intensely sheared. The last 30 feet is hard and silicious.  The trench was sampled in 10 foot sections.  The first 90 feet assayed trace to 0.01 oz/t gold, with the next 10 foot section assaying 0.14 oz/t gold and the final 10 foot section assaying 0.02 oz/t gold.

'E' Zone

The 'E' zone is sixty meters southwest of the 'D' Zone is a 60 meter wide carbonated gabbro zone containing 15-20% quartz stringers up to 0.61 meters wide striking with and across the zone. The zone contains up to 2% pyrite and considerable green mica (fuchsite). The zone shows remarkable similiarities to the Kerr Addison Mine.  The zone consists of 9 trenches over a strike length of about 150 feet within a very large and impressive zone of intense quartz-carbonate-fuchsite alteration. This area is obviously an extension of 'C' and 'D' zones and can be traced to the west to the lake shore. Quartz veining is more intense here with veins as much as 3 feet wide occurring at various orientations. Two major sets appear to be present; an easterly striking set which dips steeply north or south, and a northerly striking set which dips shallowly (15°-30°) to the east. All these veins are typical gash veins - usually pinching out over short (50-100 feet) distances. Five random chip samples were taken from trenches in this zone by Welcome North Mines, with the best sample returning 0.053 oz Au/ton.

The drilling by Inco between 1985-87 returned numerous gold intercepts.  It appears that their best intersections came from a zone they dubbed the 'Rainbow Zone', which seems to align with the 'C' zone identified by Welcome North Mines.  Some of the better drill intercepts reported were:

  • 2.25 meters of 3.1 g/t Au
  • 4.72 meters of 3.5 g/t Au (DDH-70465)
  • 0.38 meters of 96.0 g/t Au (DDH-70449)
  • 1.46 meters of 5.4 g/t Au
  • 0.49 meters of 31.0 g/t Au (DDH-70471)

The Ministry website for the Penn Gold Occurrence (UTM Zone 15, 435917E, 5455127N, NAD 83) lists Inco's best assay as 0.18 oz/t (5.6 g/t) gold over 10 meters from DDH-70465 located approximately 300 meters east of the occurrence.  The hole intersected altered gabbro and minor quartz veins from 144 to 184 meters that returned up to 24.9 g/t gold. (Canadian Nickel Assessment Files 52F04NW).

Summary

The property is located in a structurally favourable area on the hinge of a fold and hosts highly silicified, carbonatized gabbros and sericite schists, which are similar to the Dogpaw Prospect between Cameron Lake and Beggs Lake.  Five gold-bearing zones have been located within the property.  One of these zones, dubbed the 'Rainbow Zone' (Welcome North Mines 'C' zone) has been drilled along strike for 300 meters and is open at depth.  The property hosts relatively unexplored prospects with good potential for development of a large tonnage of low grade gold mineralization.  The "A" zone in particular appears to be 50-100 feet wide and may strike for as much as 3,600 feet and has seen very limited drilling.

The Cameron Lake gold deposit, owned by Coventry Resources is just 12 km northeast of the property and contains an estimated 12.2 million tonnes grading 2.11 g/t gold (1.4 million ounces).  Coventry is currently active in the area and is exploring additional area deposits as well as upgrading resources at the Cameron Lake Deposit.

In addition to the property's gold zone, the gabbro should be evaluated for its PGE potential.  It is not believed that the PGE potential has ever been considered, and that future sampling should be assayed for the PGE suite of elements.

name: Perch Lake
description: The Perch Lake property straddles a 6.5 kilometre section of the Terrace Bay batholith contact.  The vast majority of gold occurrences, and past producers in the Schreiber-Terrace Bay-Jackfish Lake area are scattered along this contact.
body:
Introduction

The Perch Lake property consists of 60 unpatented claim units and is located in the western portion of the Hemlo-Schreiber greenstone belt a distance of 210 kilometres east of Thunder Bay.  The property straddles a 6.5 kilometre section of the Terrace Bay batholith contact stretching from the Aguasabon River in the west to Bews Lake in the east.  The vast majority of gold occurrences, and past producers in the Schreiber-Terrace Bay-Jackfish Lake area are scattered along this contact.  The underground workings of the Empress gold mine are just 5 kilometres from the eastern boundary and the Jedder gold occurrence just 3 kilometres from the western boundary.

Location

The property has excellent access.  An all-weather gravel logging road cuts through the central part of the property just north of the Terrace Bay Airport.  The Trans-Canada highway cuts across the western section of the property.

Geology

The property is located within the Wawa sub-province of the Superior structural province near the western end of the Hemlo-Schreiber greenstone belt.  The dominant rock type consists of mafic volcanics and iron formation which have been intruded by quartz-feldspar porphyry dikes related to the batholith.  The property covers the contact of the batholith between the Empress Mine and the Jeddar veins at Hays Lake.  Alteration zones, and quartz/quartz-carbonate veins commonly occur near the contact zone between the mafic volcanics and the granite batholith.  In addition are numerous mapped exhalative horizons (Bartley, Harcourt, 1938) which may represent distal portions of volcanogenic base-metal deposits.  Properties such as the Harkness-Hays, Gold Range, Hays Lake and Empress, which have undergone minor development and production are all associated with the contact zone of the Terrace Bay batholith.

The two most important exploration criteria are: (1) evidence of hydrothermal fracturing and alteration, and (2) rocks that are attributable to felsic magmatism.  Adoption of these criteria have led to success at Hemlo, both in characterizing mineralization and in finding additional auriferous zones.  It is believed that similar success can be realized in the Schreiber area (Schneiders, MNDM, Thunder Bay).

Previous Exploration

Sporadic exploration has been reported in the area since the late 1890's, but is not well documented.  More recently, an electro-magnetic airborne survey was flown in 1971, and some spotty exploration conducted during the Hemlo rush in 1982.

The Empress gold mine is a mere 4 kilometers to the east along strike of our claim block.  The Empress, was discovered in 1895 and produced gold until 1900.  Native gold is found with pyrite and small amounts of other sulphides in two parallel zones of quartz veins about 150 feet apart.  The granite contact is a few hundred feet to the south.

Summary

There is a one kilometre wide alteration zone associated with the volcanic-batholith contact. There are over 30 gold occurrences associated with the western 10 km portion (Aguasabon River to Worthington Bay).  There are over 20 gold showings along the eastern 20 km section of the contact (Bews Lake to Jackfish Bay).  Ironically, there have been no documented occurrences along this portion.  The lack of success may be, in part, attributed to overburden cover in the western half of the property.  With so many gold occurrences both east and west of the property, it stands to reason that the 6.5 kilometer section of this same contact on the property should host several more, yet un-discovered occurrences.

name: Galoche Lake
description: The Property contains the eastern portion of a mafic-ultramafic intrusion with potential to host a disseminated Cu-Ni-PGE deposit, as well as being immediately along strike of a high-grade gold zone consisting of sheared granitoid rock grading up to 16.95 g/t Au.
body:
Access

Access to the property is via the Twist Lake Road, a reasonably well-kept, former logging road that originates from the town of Manitouwadge.  Alternatively, one can drive to the south end of Dead Otter Lake, and then boat to the east end of the northern arm of Dotted Lake.

Geology

Foliated mafic volcanic rocks trend east-northeast across the northern end of the property.  In the north-central part of the claim block, a 300 meter wide gabbro sill intrudes the mafic volcanics.  Immediately to the south of the gabbro unit is a serpentized peridotite.  The southernmost part of the claim block consists of foliated biotite-quartz monzonite or granodiorite.

Previous Work in the Area

1957 - Robert Fairservice discovered a zinc showing near the north arm (west shore) of Dotted Lake.  The showing lies within a sheared, garnetiferous amphibolite and possibly metamorphosed iron formation.

1965 - Irish Copper Mines flew an airborne survey of the area surrounding the north part of Dotted Lake.  The results of the survey identified a large section of high magnetic activity.  They interpreted this to be mafic and ultramfic intrusives and suggested that the area may be the northern limb of a folded structure similar to the one at Manitouwadge.

1970 - Irish Copper Mines performed a ground Mag/EM survey over the lake area to further delineate the mafic/ultramafic rocks mapped on the north shore of Dotted Lake.  A number of conductive zones identified from both the 1965 and 1970 surveys were never followed up.

1983 - Clear Mines flew an airborne survey and performed geological mapping, geochem (577 soil samples) and prospecting on the north end of Dotted Lake.  They identified a number of significant soil anomalies.  Of particular interest was a 3-line Ni-Co-As anomaly on the east part of their property that indicated potential for magmatic disseminated sulphide mineralization in the gabbro.  They recommended follow up work including trenching.

1984 - Clear Mines performed a ground mag/VLF survey.

1991 - Noranda Exploration performed mag, VLF-EM (EM-16 unit), HLEM (MaxMin) surveys and three diamond drill holes.  The surveys identified a number of mag anomalies and VLF conductors.  The HLEM survey defined two important conductors (H1 and H2).  H1 is aligned with the eastern strike extension of the Fairservice Zinc Occurrence, while H2 was presumed to map lenses of sulphides associated within the gabbro.  Noranda drilled three holes, 1.8 km apart, along the zinc horizon.  The HLEM conductor (H2) in the gabbro was not drilled.

2005-2010 – Rouge Resources conducted Mag/VLF/EM, geochem and trenching on the northwest side of Dotted Lake.  The 2010 trenching program uncovered a high-grade gold zone consisting of sheared granitoid rock with 5-10% pyrite, strong sericite and a trace of arsenopyrite.  The zone assayed up to 16.95 g/t Au in grab samples and 9.02 g/t Au over 0.4 meters in a channel sample.

Summary

The relatively recent discovery by Rouge Resources of high-grade gold in granitoid rock close to the mafic-ultramafic intrusion has brought new interest into the area.  Noranda’s work in 1991 identified a significant HLEM conductor (H2) that appears to lie along strike of Rouge’s new find.  There exists high potential for similar mineralization along strike within the Galoche Lake Property.

Further, Nickel One has found remnant ultramafic rocks containing Cu-Ni-PGE in the Bulldozer Lake Intrusion immediately east of the property in two discrete showings (Tyko and Tyko North).

Tyko Showing

TK-06-01 - 4.1 meters 1.09% Ni, 0.77% Cu, 0.42 g/t Pt, 0.42 g/t Pd

Tyko North Showing

TK-06-3 - 4.1 meters 1.07% Ni, 0.51% Cu, 0.24 g/t Pt, 0.12 g/t Pd

TK-06-5 - 6.2 meters 1.05% Ni, 0.47% Cu, 0.20 g/t Pt, 0.12 g/t Pd

The Galoche Lake Property shows similarities to the Nickel One Project in that it contains the extension of a mafic-ultramafic intrusion with potential to host a disseminated Cu-Ni-PGE deposit.

Finally, the zinc-bearing magnetite iron formation that hosts the Fairservice Occurrence to the west, strikes across the full length of the property.  Due to the area’s lack of detailed ground work, the Galoche Lake Property is an extremely attractive grass roots project.

name: Minnow Lake
description: The Minnow Lake claims contain iron formation, felsic fragmental rocks and carbonate alteration within mafic volcanics that are associated with EM conductors.
body:
Introduction

The Minnow Lake property consists of 28 unpatented claim units about 200 kilometres east of Thunder Bay.  The property has excellent access, with an all-weather gravel logging road, just north of the Trans-Canada highway, cutting across the claims.

Geology

The property is located within the Wawa sub-province of the Superior structural province near the western end of the Hemlo-Schreiber greenstone belt.  The dominant rock type consists of mafic volcanics and iron formation which have been intruded by quartz-feldspar porphyry dikes related to the batholith.  The property covers two exhalative horizons (Map 47J, Bartley, Harcourt, 1938).  Properties such as the Harkness-Hays, Gold Range, Hays Lake and Empress, which have undergone minor development and production are all associated with exhalative horizons near the contact zone of the Terrace Bay batholith.

Area Exploration

Sporadic exploration has been reported in the area since the late 1890's, but is not well documented.  More recently, an electro-magnetic airborne survey was flown in 1971, and some spotty exploration conducted during the Hemlo rush in 1982.  The Empress gold mine is five kilometers to the east along strike of the Minnow Lake property.  The Empress, was discovered in 1895 and produced gold until 1900.  Native gold is found with pyrite and small amounts of other sulphides in two parallel zones of quartz veins about 150 feet apart.  The granite contact is a short distance to the south.

Targets

There are two EM conductors that traverse across the Minnow Lake claims.  The southern conductor is associated with a magnetic low and lies very close to the batholith contact.  The mag low could represent a zone of weakness along this section of the batholith, and consequently, be an area favourable to mineralization along a fault structure.  The northern conductor is associated with a magnetic high.  Iron formation adjacent to a felsic fragmental unit containing carbonate alteration have been noted in this area along a prominent shear zone.  Both conductors represent high priority targets.

name: Hays Lake
description: The Hays Lake property is host to eight gold showings ranging from 2.0 g/t to 5.5 g/t and lies just 500 meters from the Derraugh-Jeddar main vein where small-scale mining has taken place.
body:
Location and Access

The Hays Lake property consists of 5 claims (74 units) in Priske Township in the Thunder Bay Mining Division.  The property is just a short 5 km drive east from the town of Schreiber along the Hays Lake road off the Trans-Canada highway. 

Geology

The property is underlain primarily by mafic volcanics immediately north of the Terrace Bay syenite batholith.  The volcanics have been intruded by diorite, iron formation and quartz-feldspar porphyry dikes.  The eastern-most part of the property straddles the Aguasabon River and is till-covered.

Local Mineralization and Showings

A number of gold-bearing veins in the immediate area of the property have been found associated with the contact of quartz-feldspar porphyries and iron formations.  Some of the more notable occurrences that lie in close proximity to the Hays Lake property are as follows:

Derraugh-Jeddar (Acker) Occurrence – consists of a quartz vein hosted by pyritic, basaltic flows which are intruded by a pink, fine grained to aphanitic quartz feldspar dike. The vein strikes 60 degrees and dips 85 degrees north. The average width of the vein is about 50 cm and it has been exposed over a length of approximately 150 m. The vein occupies a shear zone and consists of white, glassy quartz which in places is highly brecciated and carries pyrite, chalcopyrite, galena, gold and silver.  Jedder Gold Mines (1937) surface sampling reportedly indicated a 152.4 m section averaging 0.23 oz/ton Au over an average width of 0.46 m.  In 1972, Walter Acker constructed a small-scale gold mill on site and bulk sampled (500 lbs/hr).

Joa-Walton Occurrence - consists of three separate veins with a combined strike length of 120 metres.  Grab samples of altered volcanics and quartz porphyry have returned 0.14 oz/ton Au and 0.20 oz/t Au respectively.  Grab samples from the veins commonly assay in excess of 1.0 oz/t Au, and have assayed as high as 6.80 oz/t Au.

Singleton-Gray Occurrence - may represent an extension of the same vein system as the Joa-Walton Occurrence.  Samples from the southern zone have yielded values up to 0.558 oz/t Au and 1.00 oz/t Ag with samples from the northern zone assaying up to 1.323 oz/t Au.

Otisse Mine - was first explored in 1896 when five veins were discovered.  The main showing consists of a 9 meter wide band of iron formation striking 35° with a vertical dip.  The iron formation is well mineralized with disseminated pyrite, chalcopyrite and pyrrhotite, as well as some graphite and galena. Two shafts were sunk of the main vein where visible gold was noted with considerable pyrite in blue grey quartz.  Good grade values across 2.4 meter and 3.05 meter widths were reported from the iron formation by past owners. The main vein was sampled by J.E. Crookston (1938) and returned values of 2.44 oz/ton Au over 30 cm and 2.16 oz/ton Au over 46 cm.

Property Mineralization and Potential

In 2002, George Daniels (local prospector) spent four days prospecting within the current property.  He located eight gold showings ranging from 2.0 g/t to 5.5 g/t in his limited reconnaissance.  The Hays Lake property is just 500 meters from the Derraugh-Jeddar main vein where small-scale mining has taken place.  Further, there are two iron formations noted within the property boundary.  One of these iron formations is mapped as lying adjacent to a felsic fragmental unit.  These iron formations are well-documented to contain high-grade gold in this area.  In light of this, there exists excellent potential for a significant discovery within the Hays Lake property.

name: Cobble Lake
description: The 20-unit Cobble Lake property surrounds a single patent that contains a Co-Ta showing which has assayed up to 1.85 percent Cb2O5 and 0.17 percent Ta2O2.  The pegmatite body that hosts the showing strikes across the property for a distance of 2.5 km.
body:
Location and Access

The property is located 70 km east of the city of Kenora and 70 km west of the town of Dryden in northwestern Ontario. The Cobble Lake property consists of two claims containing 20 units in Bridges Township.  Access to the property is via a logging road north from the Trans Canada Highway. The Trans Canada Pipeline, the Canadian National Railway and the Canadian Pacific Railway all lie parallel to the Trans Canada Highway.

Geology

The rocks of the Kenora area are Archean in age and are found within the Wabigoon Subprovince of the Superior Province. The area is bordered to the north by the Winnipeg River Subprovince, and to the south by the Dryberry Batholith. It consists of the Vermillion Bay greenstone belt along with numerous granitoid intrusions.  The geology of the Kenora area consists of volcanic and sedimentary rocks intercalated with each other and then intruded by felsic intrusions. Volcanic rocks, consisting of flows and pyroclastics, form an east?trending belt through the Kenora property, ranging in widths of 0.8 km to 2.8 km. The sedimentary portion to the south of the volcanic belt is also east?trending and consists of sandstones, siltstones and argillites. The sedimentary rocks are intruded by gabbro sills and pegmatite dykes. Rocks are regionally metamorphosed to lower amphibolite to upper greenschist facies.

The peninsula that extends northeastward from the south shore of Cobble Lake is underlain by peridotite and pyroxenite intruded by pink, coarse-grained pegmatite dikes.  The muscovite-bearing pegmatite trends easterly through the centre of the claim, dips sub-vertically, and has a maximum width of 150 feet (46 m). Microcline, perthitic microcline, and quartz are the major mineral constituents, and biotite, muscovite and tourmaline occur in lesser amounts.

Previous Work

In the early 1950's, H. A. Harrison of Eagle River staked one patented claim (K16777) on the peninsula and explored the property for its mica potential.  An adit was driven from the south side of the peninsula in a northward direction for a distance of 18 feet (5.5 m) (circa 1952).

During 1953 and 1954, six diamond drill holes, totaling 206 feet (62.8 meters), were put down on the property. Some mica was shipped to General Electric in Toronto but the quantity or value of the shipment is not known.

In 1955 Harrison and D. F. Parrott of Red Lake re-examined the property for tantalum and columbium. 

Mineralization

Minor blue-green garnet and rare tantalite-columbite have been identified by Parrott.  Black tourmaline locally forms up to 10% of the pegmatite mass and can be readily observed in the dike, between 100 and 300 feet (30-90 meters) west of the adit. Individual crystals range up to 10 inches (25 cm) in length and 2.5 inches (5.3 cm) in diameter.  Biotite books, up to 5 inches (13 cm) in diameter, and 2 inches (5 cm) thick, form about 5% of the pegmatite mass.  Muscovite is segregated in small lenses in the pegmatite.  The largest muscovite zone occurs near the entrance of the adit, strikes easterly, and dips vertically.  This (muscovite) zone has a maximum thickness of 2 feet (0.6 meters) and can be traced on the surface for a distance of 30 feet (9 meters). The east end of the zone is under water.

A 50-foot (15 meter) horizontal diamond-drill hole, located about 200 feet (60 meters) west of the adit, intersected a muscovite-bearing zone about 20 feet (6 meters) wide. The muscovite has a light greenish brown colour and forms books up to 18 inches (46 cm) in diameter, and up to 5 inches (13 cm) thick. Most of the larger books contain structural imperfections known as 'A' reeves and wedge structure.

In 1955, Parrott collected a sample of pegmatite near the entrance to the adit. The sample contained 1.85 percent Cb2O5 and 0.17 percent Ta2O2 (Assessment Files, Regional Geologist's Office, Kenora). Duplicate check samples sent to the Department of Mines Laboratory and Warnock Hersey, assayed 0.42 percent and 0.10 percent Cb2O5 and 0.01 percent and 0.04 percent Cb, respectively (assessment files).

Summary

A large muscovite-bearing pegmatite trends through the centre of the property.  Blue-green garnet, tourmaline and tantalite-columbite have been identified in the pegmatite.  Sampling of a 0.6 meter muscovite-rich section of the pegmatite near the adit has assayed up to 1.85 percent Cb2O5 and 0.17 percent Ta2O2.  Drilling 60 meters west of the adit has intersected the muscovite-bearing zone over a thickness of 6 meters.  Drill logs have not been located, but it is presumed that the core would have been only assayed for its mica content.  The pegmatite body strikes for a distance of 2.5 km across the property.  In lieu of the documented tantalum mineralization, and the vintage of limited exploration, the Cobble Lake property would appear to have high potential for an economic tantalum discovery.

name: Mavis Lake
description: The 17-unit Mavis Lake property lies within the extension (boundary zone) of the Cat Lake - Winnipeg River Pegmatite Field, one of most important domains of rare metal (tantalum) mineralization in the Canadian Shield and host to the world-class Tanco tantalum mine.  Significant rare element mineralizing systems with appreciable values of tantalum, cesium, beryllium, rubidium and tin have been previously identified by the Ontario Geological Survey on the property.
body:
Location and Access

The Mavis Lake Tantalum Property is located in the Kenora Mining Division about 10 km northeast of the town of Dryden, Ontario in Brownridge Township.  The claim group can be reached by taking the Thunder Lake Road north from Highway 17 about 7 km east of Dryden. The Ghost Lake Road, a gravel road, branches to the north off of the Thunder Lake Road. The Ghost Lake Road can be followed for about a kilometer to a four way intersection which lies just inside the southern boundary of the claim group.  The Mine Road which branches to the right off of the four way intersection provides access to the southeastern portions of the claim group before continuing on to the adjoining patented mining claims of Mr. Fairservice.  The northern road from the four way intersection is the Ghost Lake Road which provides access to the northeastern extremities of the property. The West Ghost Lake Road departs the intersection to the west and provides ready access to the central portions of the property. An ATV road in the southwestern portion of the claim group connects to the West Ghost Lake Road several hundred metres to the west of the intersection. Large tracts of timber have been harvested in the central portions of the property. A number of rough logging roads branch off of the West Ghost Lake Road and are suitable for ATV travel.

Geology

The property lies in the Sioux Lookout Domain which is characterized by an alternating series of southward facing metavolcanic and metasedimentary rocks. The property is dominantly composed of pillowed and massive mafic metavolcanics of the Brownridge Volcanics. Brownridge metasediments may underlie the southern extremity of the property but did not outcrop. The Brownridge assemblage is intruded by granites related to the fertile peraluminous Ghost Lake batholith. A pegmatite field related to the Ghost Lake batholith traverses the claim group and ranges from beryl-type (True North Gems) to the west of the property to albite-type (Fairservice) lying to the east of the property.

Previous Work

The geology of the region was mapped by the Ontario Department of Mines: W. Moorhouse in the Eagle Lake area in 1941 and by J. Satterly in the Wabigoon area in 1943. Further government work was carried out by F. Breaks et al (1976, 1978, 1980, and 1984) and more recently by G. Beakhouse in 2001 and 2002. More recent focused studies of the rare metal potential of the region was carried out by Breaks et al in 2001 and 2003. Airborne magnetic and electromagnetic surveys were conducted in the Dryden area (1997) and in the Stormy Lake areas (2001).

Mineral exploration in the region has principally focused on rare metals and tungsten.  From 1955 to 1964, lithium was the main target while in the 1960's tungsten and tantalum were featured. More recent exploration has focused on emeralds and tantalum mineralization.  Lun-Echo Gold Mines Limited carried out trenching and a 40 hole, 1968m. diamond drilling program following the discovery of spodumene pegmatites near Mavis Lake in 1956. The drilling defined lithium mineralization over a strike length of 670m. This exploration took place on the patented claims (Fairservice Property) which adjoin the Mavis Lake Property to the east.

In 1964 a spodumene-pollucite-bearing complex pegmatite was discovered near Tot Lake which lies about 20km.to the northeast of Ghost Lake Property. J. Donner investigated the mineralization by geological mapping and magnetic surveys followed by a 4 hole, 223m. diamond drilling program in 1973.

A. Petrunka discovered tungsten mineralization near Sharpe Lake in the late 1960's and initial evaluation was undertaken by Noranda Mines Limited. In 1982 Sanmine Exploration Inc. carried out extensive trenching and diamond drilling programs on the Petrunka claims. A series of pits and trenches within the southern portions of the Mavis Lake Property may mark the westernmost extension of these investigations.

Selco Mining Corporation Limited carried out geological mapping, lithium geochemical surveys and diamond drilling over the Mavis Lake (Fairservice) spodumene pegmatites in 1979.  Tantalum Mining Corporation of Canada Limited undertook a limited diamond drilling program on the Tot Lake pegmatites.  Tantalum Mining Corporation of Canada Limited optioned the Fairservice Property in 1982 and conducted a magnetic survey before dropping their option.

In 2003 Emerald Fields Resource Corporation carried out prospecting, trenching, geological mapping and a 4 hole diamond drilling program on the Fairservice claims.  In 2003 True North Gems Inc. carried out prospecting, stripping and sampling programs in 2003 over the Taylor Beryl (Emerald) Occurrence on a property attached to the western edge of the Mavis Lake Property.

Between 2001 and 2003, Houston Lake Mining performed line cutting, mag/vlf and geological mapping and sampling on our current holdings.  Their mapping identified numerous tourmaline-bearing pegmatites throughout the volcanic pile. The pegmatites located by Houston Lake occurred as small pods or lenses (several cm in width) which crosscut the foliation as well large bodies tens of metres across concordant to the foliation.

Mineralization

Significant rare element mineralizing systems with appreciable values of tantalum, cesium, beryllium, rubidium and tin have been previously identified by the Ontario Geological Survey ("OGS") on the property. Reported values of the OGS include 186 g/t (0.019%) tantalum oxide and 115 g/t (0.012%) tin (E. Berger, 1990) and 179 g/t (0.018%) tantalum oxide (F. Breaks, 1991).  The high concentration and potential of the Mavis Lake property is emphasized by an elevated tantalum to niobium ratio of approximately 3:1. Pronounced and broad lithium (holmquistite) and boron (tourmaline) anomalies are traceable for over 650 metres on the property and elsewhere have proven to be important pathfinders to rare metal (tantalum) mineralization. Breaks confirms that some gem quality emeralds occur within the Boundary Zone.

The Mavis Lake property also encompasses the Petrunka (Sanmine) Tungsten Occurrence. The tungsten mineralization coincides with a mafic volcanic sequence. Tungsten is used to strengthen metal alloys and is trading at USD $40/kg

Summar

The property lies within the extension (boundary zone) of the Cat Lake - Winnipeg River Pegmatite Field, one of most important domains of rare metal (tantalum) mineralization in the Canadian Shield and host to the world-class Tanco tantalum mine.  Significant rare element mineralizing systems with appreciable values of tantalum, cesium, beryllium, rubidium and tin have been previously identified by the Ontario Geological Survey ("OGS") on the property.  In addition, the property has significant potential for tungsten and gem quality emeralds. 

Houston Lake produced values up to 105ppm Li, 48.8ppm Cs. and 1170ppm Rb from limited sampling.  These values are indicative of rare metal enrichment.  They noted that " Key zones at Locality A and B remain as yet un-sampled and are worthy of follow up." (Grayme Anthony, Timberwolf Explorations, 2004

The property covers 2 km of the important Brownridge sediment/volcanic contact trend. This contact appears to be a key control on rare metal mineralization in the region.  Both the highly evolved Spodumene-Beryl-Tantalite Zone (Fairservice Property) located just to the east of the Mavis Lake Property and the less evolved Beryl-Columbite Zone (Taylor Emerald Occurrence, Petrunka Tungsten Occurrence) to the west of the property occur along this important contact

Geological mapping has successfully identified a second rare metals zone that extends the Holmquistite Zone of Breaks and Janes (1991) for over 1.6 km across the Mavis Lake Property. Tourmaline mineralization is ubiquitous along this zone and is indicative of rare metal mineralization. Tourmaline contains boron, an important complexing agent for the transport and deposition of rare metals. Holmquistite is also a positive indicator of lithium and rare metal mineralization. Two localities, A and B, have been previously identified by Houston Lake for follow up sampling based on geological mapping rather than sampling results.  Locality B, in particular, contains a large potassic pegmatite

Recommendation

Stripping of localities A and B are recommended as well as Enzyme leach soil geochemistry for areas of little outcrop along both rare metal trends, with special attention on the Brownridge sediment/volcanic contact.

name: Medicine Lake
description: The 15-unit Medicine Lake property covers a large (460 meter wide x 600 meter long) pegmatite intrusion.  Beryl mineralization over a width of 12 meters across a strike length of 127 metres has assayed up to 13.6% beryllium oxide. Crystals of tantalite have been found in three pits along a 100 meter strike length.
body:
Location and Access

The property is located 65 km east of the city of Kenora and 80 km west of the town of Dryden in northwestern Ontario. The Medicine Lake property consists of a single claim containing 15 units in Tustin Township.  Access to the property is via the Gordon Lake road 4 km north of the Trans Canada Highway. The Trans Canada Pipeline, the Canadian National Railway and the Canadian Pacific Railway all lie parallel to the Trans Canada Highway.

Geology

The rocks of the Kenora area are Archean in age and are found within the Wabigoon Subprovince of the Superior Province. The area is bordered to the north by the Winnipeg River Subprovince, and to the south by the Dryberry Batholith. It consists of the Vermillion Bay greenstone belt along with numerous granitoid intrusions.  The geology of the Kenora area consists of volcanic and sedimentary rocks intercalated with each other and then intruded by felsic intrusions. Volcanic rocks, consisting of flows and pyroclastics, form an east?trending belt through the Kenora property, ranging in widths of 0.8 km to 2.8 km. The sedimentary portion to the south of the volcanic belt is also east?trending and consists of sandstones, siltstones and argillites. The sedimentary rocks are intruded by gabbro sills and pegmatite dykes. Rocks are regionally metamorphosed to lower amphibolite to upper greenschist facies.

Previous Work

Uranium was first discovered in the Kenora area in 1949 near the shore of Willard Lake. This was followed by the discovery of the high?grade Richard Lake deposit by Campbell and McFarland in the early 1950’s.  The Richard Lake deposit has been estimated at 590,000 tonnes of 0.10% U3O8 (Palmer, 2007).

In 1949, beryl in pegmatite was discovered at the east end of Medicine Lake. The occurrence was initially found and staked by E. Sobiski.  Trenching and stripping were carried out in 1949 to determine the extent of beryl mineralization. Part of the pegmatite exposed by this work is presently covered by the Gordon Lake Development Road.

In 1958, Conquest Exploration Limited blasted five trenches and drilled two diamond-drill holes, totaling 509 feet (155 meters), on a zone of sulphide mineralization located about 1,400 feet (430 m) northeast of the east end of Medicine Lake.

Between 1966 and 1970, Falconbridge Nickel Mines performed geological mapping, ground geophysics, and diamond drilling in the area to investigate the ultramafic intrusions for copper and nickel mineralization.  Two inclined diamond-drill holes, totaling 1,234 feet (376 meters) were drilled from the surface of Medicine Lake during the winter of 1970.  Drill logs and assays have not been located.

During 2008 Delta Uranium Canada completed a sampling program totaling 2,590 samples on its large 'Kenora Project' using a scintillometer (RS?125 Super Spec).  They sampled the Medicine Lake Beryl Occurrence and got up to 632 counts per second U3O8.

Beryl-Tantalum Mineralization

The pegmatite intrusion on the property underlies the area between Medicine Lake and Lift Lake.  It has an approximate width of 1,500 feet (460 m) and a length of 2,000 feet (600 m), and is oriented in a northeasterly direction. The pegmatite is white to grey in colour, with local areas that are pink. It is medium to very coarse grained, and is composed of feldspar and quartz with minor amounts of biotite and muscovite, and rare black tourmaline, red garnet, yellow to clear beryl and black tantalite.  The accessory minerals generally have well-developed crystal shapes. Beryl crystals at the main showing occur over an area 120 feet (37 meters) long and 40 feet (12 meters) wide. E. Sobiski reported that he also found small crystals of beryl about 300 feet (90 meters) southeast of the main showing.

In 1950, E. O. Chisholm examined and described the Medicine Lake Beryl Tantalum Occurrence as follows:  "Beryl crystals up to 2 inches [5 cm] in diameter and several inches [cm] long occur in a coarse grained pegmatite to the west of the cabin . . . A total of 20 (beryl crystals) were observed in an area 25 feet long [7.6 meters] and 5 feet [1.5 meter] wide. The average diameter of the crystals was from half an inch to an inch [1.3 cm-2.5 cm].  The beryl crystals appeared to be confined to a coarser phase of the pegmatite in this locality.  Large crystals of white and grey perthitic feldspar up to a foot [0.3 meter] across accompany the beryl mineralization. Thin sheets of biotite mica several inches in length often occur along the crystal faces of the feldspar. Small patches and crystals of black tourmaline up to an inch [2.5 cm] in diameter were noticed.  A piece of one of the larger beryl crystals was sent to Beryllium Corporation for assay by the claim owner. It was reported to contain 13.6 percent beryllium oxide. A sample of the massive grey perthite was reported to contain 1 percent beryllium oxide (Statistical Files, ODM)."

Crystals of tantalite were found by Chisholm in a pit located 75 feet (22.8 meters) northeast of the cabin (main beryl showing). The Gordon Lake development road lies immediately north of this pit. Chisholm also reported the presence of tantalite crystals in a 25-foot (7.6 meter) long trench located about 100 feet (30 m) north of the above-mentioned pit.  Scattered crystals of tantalite, up to one inch (2.5 cm) in diameter, were observed by Chisholm in an outcrop of white, medium-grained pegmatite along the north side of the Gordon Lake development road, about 225 feet (70 meters) northwest of the above-mentioned pit.

Nickel Mineralization

The sulphide zone located by Conquest Exploration, strikes easterly, dips vertically, and has been traced for a length of 600 feet (180 meters). At the west end of the mineralized zone, massive and disseminated pyrrhotite and minor pyrite, in metasediments, are exposed over a width of 30 feet (9 meters). A grab sample of massive sulphides collected by the OGS was found to contain 0.07 percent nickel. Mineralization at the east end of the zone consists of disseminated pyrrhotite in mafic schists. The mineralized zone has a maximum thickness of 40 feet (12 meters) and is in sharp contact with garnetiferous metasediments.  Some pyrite is present in the metasediments. Pyrrhotite forms 2-5% of the mafic schists and a grab sample collected by Chisholm from trench 1, was found to contain about 0.02 percent nickel.

Summary

The pegmatite intrusion on the property is quite large (460 meters wide by 600 meters long) and has been shown to contain black tourmaline, red garnet, yellow to clear beryl and black tantalite.  Sampling has shown beryl mineralization over a width of 12 meters across a strike length of 127 metres.  Beryl crystals sent out for assay have been shown to contain up to 13.6% beryllium oxide.  Crystals of tantalite were found by Chisholm in three pits along a 100 meter strike length, although no assays were provided.  In lieu of the documented tantalum mineralization, and the vintage of limited exploration, the Medicine Lake property would appear to have high potential for an economic tantalum discovery.

name: Victoria Lake
description: Four strong hydrothermal alteration cells have been identified on the Victoria Lake property which represent a long lived hydrothermal system.  Further, a nickel-copper-PGE deposit lies immediately adjacent to the property and dips onto our claims.  Grab samples taken from the deposit have assayed as high as 5.7% Nickel, 1.3% copper, 0.09% cobalt, 0.44 g/t palladium and 0.11 g/t platinum.
body:
Access

The property is located on the western end of the Schreiber Volcanic belt, part of the Abitibi Wawa Greenstone belt of the Superior Structural Province. The Victoria Lake property is located approximately 6 km north of the town of Schreiber. Access is gained off the Winston Lake mine road just south of Sammy's Lake. An old drill road provides access to the property.  The old drill road is driveable by 4x4 for the first 2 km and then by all-terrain vehicle for the remainder.

VMS Potential

Previous Exploration

Circa 1930: Trenching was conducted on the iron formations and gossans in the area.

1983: Noranda Exploration conducts reconnaissance investigations. Geological mapping and geophysical surveys including mag, Max Min Horizontal Loop and PEM surveys were conducted. Areas of hydrothermal alteration are recognized.

1984: Noranda Exploration drilled 4 holes totalling 699 m, as well as conducting downhole pulse surveys. 1985: Noranda Exploration conducts 878 m of diamond drilling on the property as well as downhole PEM survey.

1987: Geological mapping and 1558 m of diamond drilling are conducted. Downhole pulse survey is conducted. Minor base metal values (<1100 ppm Zn) are intersected.

1990: Minnova Inc. options the property from Noranda Exploration and Cumberland resources Ltd. who are in joint venture. Detailed geological mapping is conducted and several favourable alteration zones and synvolcanic structures are defined.

1991-1992:Minnova Inc. conducts diamond drilling and downhole geophysical surveys.

Geology

The general geology of the Victoria Lake VMS claims are described by Glenn (1991) as follows: Generalized geology of the southern limb of the belt is summarised by a thick sequence of metavolcanic and metasedimentary units possibly synclinal folded about an east plunging east west axis. The metavolcanics dominate forming three mafic to felsic cycles. A typical cycle is characterised by a thick sequence of pillowed to massive basalts grading upward into andesite and finally massive felsic flows. Metasedimentary units consist of greywacke, chert carbonate, argillite, arkose, and graphitic shale with interlayered pyrite and pyrrhotite. Well preserved primary sedimentary textures indicate that the volcanic sedimentary sequence was deposited subaqueously. All units have been metamorphosed to amphibolite grade of regional metamorphism. The metamorphic grade increases to upper amphibolite to the north.

Mineralization and Alteration

Several gossans and disseminated interpillow sulphides occur within the Corvette Lake mafic flows. Base metal values up to 4200 ppm Zn were encountered (Glenn, 1991).Low to anomalous base metal values (<1100 ppm Zn and 210 ppm Cu) were intersected in oxide facies iron formation in the Victoria Lake Horizon (VL 7). An iron formation 300 m north of Victoria Lake assayed 7615 ppm Zn and 658 ppm Cu (Glenn 1991). A grab sample of felsic tuff (92 BVL-01) collected from the Anglo Lake gossan assayed 1740 ppm Zn, 397 ppm Cu and 0.002 oz/ton Au.

Four strong hydrothermal alteration cells or zones have been identified on the Victoria Lake property. The most intense alteration occurs between the Titanium fault and Hill fault. Andalusite is developed and believed to represent a long lived hydrothermal system (Glenn, 1991). Cordierite porphyroblasts also occur in a siliceous biotitic matrix.

Ni-Cu-PGE Potential

Previous Exploration

1930-36: Surface sampling and diamond drilling of 3 holes were probably undertaken by Cominco.

1937: Cook Lake Gold Mines Ltd. performed a ground mag survey.

1950: Falconbridge Nickel Mines held the property under option from D. Campbell of Schreiber. They conducted a ground mag survey and geological mapping. A detailed investigation of the mineralization was carried out and formed the basis of a bachelor's thesis by D.T. Anderson (1951).

1956: Property optioned to New Athona Mines Ltd. and Mogul Mining Corp., who drilled 4 holes totalling 516 m.

1965: Property came open and was restaked by Zenmac Metal Mines Ltd., who mapped the property and drilled 5 holes totalling 61 m along a strike length of 48.8 m on the main mineralized zone.

1969: Zenmac carried out a detailed ground mag survey, locating 4 anomalous zones. 8 holes totalling 642 m were drilled.  Zenmac Metal Mines Ltd. describes the deposit and their drill program results:

“The deposit known before this (1969) program was estimated to contain 185,000 tons grading 0.49% nickel and 0.26% copper to the 300 foot horizon in a zone 300 feet long, 22 feet thick and dipping 40 degrees. Three holes have intersected the deposit at greater depth to at least 600 feet and indicate an additional 190,000 tons grading 0.40% nickel and 0.12% copper. The grade of the central core of the deposit was calculated to be about 1.0% nickel and 0.3% copper over 5 to 15 feet.”

1970: Nicohal Mines Ltd. drilled 9 holes totalling 1231.7 m, encountering Ni-Cu mineralization.

2004: NovaWest Resources completed 11 diamond drill holes (1,502 metres). Eight of the 11 diamond drill holes intersected disseminated to semi-massive (10-15 per cent) sulphide mineralization (pyrrhotite-pyrite-chalcopyrite). The sulphide mineralization occurs as blebs or clots associated to a magnetic pyroxenite unit that is believed to have intruded the granitic rocks. Company geologists believed the sulphide clots or blebs noted within the pyroxenite dike material are from settling or coalescing, which could create significant accumulation.

Geology

The Nicopor Deposit lies immediately north of, and an adjacent to, the Victoria Lake claims.  The deposit is classed as a 'mafic-ultramafic intrusion-hosted ' deposit. The prospect occurs at the northern contact of the Schreiber greenstone belt with the Crosman Lake granitic batholith. The greenstone belt assemblage consists of an east trending, homoclinal succession of mafic to felsic metavolcanic rocks intruded by sill like gabbro bodies. In the vicinity of the Nicopor prospect the massive amphibolite host had been largely interpreted by various exploration geologists as a metamorphosed and altered mafic to intermediate volcanic rock. Recent mapping, based to a large extent on comparison with other mafic rocks nearby, suggests that this amphibolitic unit is gabbroic rather than volcanic. This interpretation also accounts to some degree for the source of the nickel and copper rich sulphide mineralization as discussed below. Base metal sulphides occur as massive to vein like and net textured aggregates in a narrow, linear zone that follows the contact between a dark green, massive amphibolite (melagabbro) on the south and medium grained, equigranular, pink granite on the north. A quartz bearing, mafic rock typically occurs between the melagabbro and the granite and has been mapped as leucogabbro, possibly representing a hybrid phase between the two main host rocks. This mineralized zone has developed a conspicuous, extensive gossan that obscures host rock and sulphide relationships. White iron hydroxides and rare malachite have developed as stains on deeply weathered sulphides. Several shallow pits have been sunk on this northeast striking zone over a distance of approximately 75 m. The sulphide zone on surface ranges up to approximately 2 m in width and rapidly grades outwards into disseminated mineralization in both the gabbro and granite. The sulphide zone is crosscut by barren aplite, syenite and feldspar porphyry dykes.

Mineralization and Alteration

The sulphide zone on surface consists mainly of semi massive, net like veinlets of pyrrhotite, with minor chalcopyrite and isolated porphyroblasts of pyrite. Pentlandite, the nickel bearing sulphide phase, is visible in cut and polished slabs and accounts for up to 15% of the sulphides in polished section. Sulphide veins and massive sulphides are apparently hosted mainly by the granite which has been brecciated by the introduced sulphides and occurs as xenoliths within them. Sulphides within the gabbro and in the granite away from the main mineralized zone tend to be fine grained, disseminated to blebby grains. Fine grained magnetite grains are disseminated throughout the gabbro and also occur as a minor component within massive sulphides. The occurrence of native copper is noteworthy in that is occurs as small, disseminated grains within granite, apparently as a hypogene, rather than a supergene mineral. Additional petrographic descriptions of the sulphides had previously been provided by Anderson (1951): Polished, thin section study reveals that the sulphides are pervasively annealed and occur usually as composite veinlets and blebs that are interstitial to silicate mineral grains in the host rocks. The granite displays an ubiquitous micrographic texture developed between quartz and alkali feldspar. In the micrographic granite, grain boundaries between sulphides and silicates are sharp and straight, whereas in the gabbro, intimately intergrown sulphides and acicular amphiboles suggest that they crystallized at the same time. Sulphides also occur along cleavage traces in these amphiboles. Pyrrhotite, the predominant sulphide, comprises aggregates that host granular veinlets and small, oriented flames and incipient veinlets of pentlandite along pyrrhotite grain boundaries. Chalcopyrite typically occurs as blebs and anhedral grains at the margins of the sulphide aggregates and locally crosscuts pentlandite.

Resident Geologist Staff visited the occurrence July 1, 1992. 7 grab samples returned copper values ranging from 80 to 10540 ppm Cu, 105 to 45250 ppm Ni, and <10 to 456 ppb Palladium. The best copper value came from an amphibole rich granite, with fine grained disseminated py, po, cp and rare native copper grains (Main trench). The best Nickel and Palladium value came from massive po, with minor cp blebs, subhedral pyrite porphyroblasts; relict patches of host granite (Main Trench dump).

Grab samples taken from the property in 1997 by Brian Fowler, assayed as high as 5.7% Nickel, 1.3% copper, 0.09% cobalt, 0.44 g/t palladium and 0.11 g/t platinum. The results of Fowler's sampling is as follows:

97-09- 36 ppb Au, 158 ppb Pd, 60 ppb Pt, 0.78% Cu, 2.92% Ni

97-10 - 24 ppb Au, 442 ppb Pd, 30 ppb Pt, 0.09% Cu, 5.70% Ni

97-11 - 56 ppb Au, 194 ppb Pd, 50 ppb Pt, 1.26% Cu, 1.44% Ni

97-12 - 64 ppb Au, 124 ppb Pd, 110 ppb Pt, 1.01% Cu, 0.60% Ni

97-13 - 36 ppb Au, 186 ppb Pd, 40 ppb Pt, 0.66% Cu, 1.55% Ni

97-14 - 32 ppb Au, 242 ppb Pd, 50 ppb Pt, 0.11% Cu, 0.66% Ni

97-15 - 24 ppb Au, 236 ppb Pd, 70 ppb Pt, 0.09% Cu, 3.27% Ni

Summary

The mineralized zone encompassing the Nicopor showing is open at depth and along strike.  The deepest drilling of the deposit by Nicohal Mines determined that the altered gabbro and mineralization increases in width at depth.  In fact their best drill holes are collared on our property and returned the following intercepts:

Hole 14 (L13E @6+50S)

Altered Gabbro from 475-562.5 feet = 87.5 feet

16.5 feet 0.32% Ni and 0.33% Cu (546-562.5 feet)

Hole 15 (L12E @ 7+50S)

Altered Gabbro from 470-622.5 feet = 152.5 feet

35.0 feet 0.44% Ni and 0.12% Cu (558-593 feet)

Hole 16 (L13E @ 7+50S)

Altered Gabbro from 417-586 feet = 169 feet

No assays

Hole 17 (L12E @ 5+00S)

Altered Gabbro from 302-486 feet = 184 feet

40 feet 0.33% Ni and 0.11% Cu (419.5-459.5 feet)

Perhaps even more important is an outcrop known as the 'East Showing', located about 1.3 kilometers east of the main Nicopor showing, which reportedly hosts nickel and copper values as well.  This showing appears to lie within a much larger unit of gabbro which lies to the south of the Nicopor host gabbro (refer to Geology Map 47j).  Sporadic traverses in the area while staking located several gabbro outcrops.

With respect to the property’s VMS potential, there is proven wide-spread VMS-style alteration on the property.  Very limited drilling has taken place over this large area.  In fact the highest zinc values returned from bedrock trenching north of Victoria Lake has never been drilled.  Nor has a strong EM conductor immediately along strike to the east.

The Victoria Lake property holds great promise for a significant find of both zinc-copper mineralization as well as nickel-copper-PGE mineralization.

name: Little Bear Lake
description: Recent exploration has uncovered three separate bedrock sources of gold, with a fourth area containing high-grade gold and silver in soil. The first area located bonanza style grades of gold up to 53.7 g/t gold and 19.25 g/t silver. A second area 200 meters to the north assayed 3.8 g/t gold. A third area to the southeast returned 18.2 g/t gold and 1.03 g/t silver in soils.
body:
Introduction

The Little Bear property consists of 48 claim units and lies 4 km north of the town of Schreiber, and 15 kilometers southeast of the past producing Winston Lake Zinc Mine. Access is via gravel road from the town of Schreiber which turns into a winter road (ATV trail) that goes to Big Duck Lake.  An old road branches off the Big Duck Lake trail just north of Cook Lake and heads east to Big Bear Lake and the property.

Regional Geology

The property lies in the east-west trending Big Duck-Schreiber greenstone belt of the Archean Abitibi-Wawa Subprovince.  In the Schreiber area the belt is composed of generally east-west trending, north-facing, mafic metavolcanics with minor metasediments and mafic intrusive rocks.  The most important structural feature of the Big Duck-Schreiber Region is the east/west trending anticline which neatly divides the area between its north limb and its south limb. The core of the anticline is occupied by a large granitic body. The anticline is cut at a high angle by F-2 synclines and anticlines.  The rock types in the southern portion of the Big Duck-Schreiber area show a lower greenschist facies metamorphic grade.

Property Geology

The property consists of basaltic flows that are separated by different types of sedimentary rock.  These sediments take the form of the typical banded oxide iron formation common in the Schreiber area. The strike of the iron formations are northwest to southeast and consist of alternating 1-2 cm wide bands of magnetite and chert. The widths vary from one to four meters. These formations can be traced across the entire width of the property.

Nearby Occurrences

Twomey Iron Formation

In 1992 a Thunder Bay prospector, Tim Twomey, sampled a 4 meter wide iron formation (location #1 on map) which returned a high of 4.85 g/t gold.  The area is underlain by mafic metavolcanic rocks, mainly pillowed and massive flows. Oxide and sulphide facies iron formation is intercalated within the metavolcanic rocks. Minor metasedimentary rocks are also present. Gabbro is also present. Schnieders et al. (1993) describes the Twomey B.I.F as: Oxide facies formation consisting of laminated magnetite and chert bands (locally jasper) is observed in several locations throughout the property. The iron formation at location #1 is hosted by fine grained, pelitic, metasedimentary rocks or mudstone, as well as greywacke and minor conglomerate. The iron formation is 3 to 4 m in width and strikes 290 degrees to 320 degrees and dips 55 degrees NE. Mafic intrusive rocks, mainly gabbro, intrude the metasedimentary rocks. Gold mineralization is associated with secondary sulphides in crosscutting fractures within the iron formation, as well as sulphide replacements of the chert and magnetite layers. Semi massive pyrite is present over widths of up to 5 cm in association with the cross fractures and replaced layers. Pyrite preferentially replaces the chert layers in a 'brickwork' type fashion. The cross fractures strike 100 degrees and are commonly associated with areas of jaspilitic iron formation.  Grab sample 92 BTT 1 collected by Resident Geologist staff consisted of pyrite rich (less than or equal to 20%) iron formation and assayed 0.156 ounces Au per ton. 

Twomey Power Line Occurrence

In addition, sampling by Twomey from a quartz vein along the power line (location #3 on map) assayed 10.48 g/t gold.  The quartz vein is associated with felsic intrusive dikes within mafic metavolcanic rocks.  The vein strikes 106 degrees and dips 70 degrees SW and has been traced for over 200 m along the power line. The vein averages 20 to 25 cm in width and displays a crack-seal texture. The quartz vein occurs in contact with a pink hornblende syenite dike, which is commonly on the footwall contact of the vein.  Several syenite dikes were observed in the area, up to l m in width. The quartz vein and syenite dikes are hosted by sheared and deformed pillowed mafic metavolcanic rocks.  Extensional, sigmoidal, quartz-filled gash veins are present within the metavolcanic host rocks. In one section, the main mineralized quartz vein displays a 20x flexure in strike. On the eastern end of the showing, approximately 300 m east of main mineralized quartz vein, several narrow, mineralized, quartz-filled gash veins are exposed within syenite dikes.  The quartz vein contains pyrite, minor chalcopyrite, tourmaline, hematite and chlorite. Samples collected and analyzed are displayed in Table 7.5 (see map).

Schreiber-Pyramid Occurrence

Immediately south of the Little Bear property boundary is the Schreiber-Pyramid Occurrence.  Previous work dates back to early 1930’s when auriferous quartz veins on the property were trenched and bulk sampled by Kenecho Gold Mines.  Records indicate that 150 tons of ore was mined at an average grade of 17.6 g/t gold from the #1 vein in 1937. 

In 1969 Zenmac Metal Mines Ltd. drilled five holes, totalling 243 meters, on a base metal showing (#2 vein) north of the Schreiber Pyramid adit (#1 vein).  Drill holes intersected minor quartz veining and pyritic shear zones, with the best intersection returning 4.6% Cu and 19.2% Zn over 0.55 meters at a vertical depth of 15.24 meters from massive sulphides (chalcopyrite-sphalerite-pyrrhotite) in a chloritic shear at a contact between volcanic and sedimentary rocks.  In 1984 Falconbridge Copper acquired the Schreiber-Pyramid property to re-evaluate its base metal potential in light of the nearby Winston Lake discovery.  Grab samples of the #2 vein by Falconbridge assayed as high as 31% zinc and a one foot channel sample yielded 13.77% zinc.  Further, a grab sample from the #1 vein directly above the Schreiber Pyramid adit, assayed 45.2 g/t Au.

In 1987, the Ministry of Northern Development of Mines visited the property and sampled both the #1 and #2 veins.  Two samples from the #1 vein assayed 13.06 g/t and 26.75 g/t.  A sample from the #2 vein assayed 17.5% copper, 7.1% zinc and 139 g/t silver. 

Little Bear Occurrence

The Little Bear Occurrence lies a short distance north of the property.  The occurrence was discovered in 1935 by E. McKenzie while surface prospecting.  A 2.4 meter by 1.5 meter shaft was sunk to a depth of 5.5 meters along with trenching and pitting.   A one ton bulk sample taken from the occurrence in 1936 was reported to have an average grade of 1,419 g/ton gold.  The claims lapsed and were re-staked by J.E. Halonen in 1946.  Spectacular samples of quartz containing visible gold and possible tellurides have been taken from the property.  The single leased claim is still held by the Halonen family.

Property Occurrences

NEW High-Grade Gold Occurrence

A work program in 2010 targeted an intense magnetic response located on the north side of a hill just south of a small pond in the southern part of the Little Bear property.  Smoky banded chert was stripped over an area 1 metre wide by 6 metres long.  The chert is highly magnetic and contains crystals of specular hematite and heavily mineralized calcite.  Assays from the zone averaged 1.5 g/t gold over the 6 meter width. The northern 2 meters of the zone carries 3.3 g/t gold.  To the south, the stripping was lost in a heavily pitted rusty rock.

In 2011, Bard Ventures conducted additional MAG/VLF surveys, followed by prospecting and sampling.  The program identified three separate areas of high potential.  The first area located bonanza style grades of gold up to 53.7 g/t gold and 19.25 g/t silver.  A second area 200 meters to the north assayed 3.8 g/t gold.  A third area to the southeast returned 18.2 g/t gold and 1.03 g/t silver in soils.  The high soils, bonanza gold values and the 2010 showing all appear to line up along a single zone that is 1.6 kilometers long.  Bard reluctantly returned the property to us as a result of poor market conditions (low share price and no cash).

Conclusion

Recent exploration has uncovered three separate bedrock sources of gold, with a fourth area containing high-grade gold and silver in soil.  The property has seen no trenching or drilling, and numerous untested EM conductors exist throughout the claim block.  There appears to be at least two favourable trends that contain highly anomalous gold mineralization, one which has been measured over a distance of 1.6 km. 

Twomey’s two discoveries indicate gold is found both within iron formation and quartz veining,  Resident Geologist staff observed several additional iron formation exposures, some previously stripped by Corporation Falconbridge Copper and others requiring further sampling and exploration for both gold and base metals. This suggests a number of parallel iron formations with potential strike lengths up to 3 km in this immediate area.

Based on the impressive showings within the property as well as potentially important high-grade base metal values (17.5% Cu - 31% Zn - 139 g/t Ag) immediately adjacent our property, the Little Bear claims have high potential to host a lode gold and/or VMS style deposit.

name: Lunny Lake
description: Drilling by Hemlo Gold in 1996 encountered 1 meter of 37.4 g/t Au just 100 meters from the property boundary.  A second drill hole, 200 meters further east, encountered 3 meters of 3.9 g/t Au, including 1 meter of 10.6 g/t Au.
body:
Location and Access

The Lunny Lake property consists of 34 units and is located about 18 kilometers northeast of Hemlo, Ontario in Thunder Bay Mining Division.  The claims are accessible by traveling north on Highway 614 from the Trans-Canada highway a distance of 14 kilometers.  From that point, a road runs north-easterly toward Dead Otter Lake and cuts the western part of the property.  A subsidiary road (Twist Lake Road) trends through the eastern portion of the claims.  The property is characterized by rolling hills with low topographic relief and timbered with spruce and balsam.

Geology

The Lunny Lake Property is located within the Archean Schreiber-Hemlo Greenstone Belt that is part of the Abitibi-Wawa Subprovince. The property is situated on the northern portion of the synform and dominated by east-west striking sequences of metavolcanic and metasedimentary rocks bounded to the south by the Musher Lake Pluton.  Mafic metavolcanic rock form the lowermost stratigraphic unit and consist of pillowed flows which grade into fine to medium and medium to coarse grained amphibolites.  Tops determination taken from pillows indicates a south younging direction. Interflow sediments, tuff and iron formation are found intermixed within the mafic flow.  A calcsilicate unit intermixed with felsic to intermediate flows and pyroclastic rocks overlies the mafic volcanic.  This sequence grades in turn into thick succession of metasediments consisting essentially of conglomerates and greywacke.  Locally the emplacement of the Dotted Lake Pluton has produced a large easterly plunging anticline.  The property is located on the southern limb of this structure.

Property Showings

McIntyre Showing #4

The host rock is an intermediate to felsic volcanic.  Drilling by McIntyre Porcupine in 1962 intersected 0.9 meters of 3.9% Cu over the showing.  Further drilling by the Falconbridge/Caravelle Mines joint venture in 1967 at the #4 showing returned the following intercepts:

  • Hole A2 – 2.5 meters of 8.2 g/t Au, 1.1% Cu, 0.8% Zn and 13.7 g/t Ag.
  • Hole W1 – 2.1 meters of 3.2 g/t Au, 2.9% Cu, 2.1% Zn and 52.8 g/t Ag.

The mineralized sections contain appreciable amounts of garnets, minor chlorite alteration and 10-15% sulphides.  Minor malachite staining and chalcopyrite is present.  Previous operators incorrectly mapped the rocks as dipping north and consequently, drilling was from the north to south.  Close examination of the rocks in the vicinity of the showing clearly demonstrate a steep south dip.  The showing dips under a creek bed, so it is not known what the true width of mineralization is.  Sampling from 2006 and 2007 was as follows:

  • Sample 2006-7 - 0.16 g/t Au, 6.6 g/t Ag, 0.42% Cu
  • Sample 2006-8 - 0.10 g/t Au, 7.0 g/t Ag, 0.48% Cu
  • Sample 2006-9 - 0.15 g/t Au, 35.0 g/t Ag, 0.13% Pb, 2.16% Cu, 0.29% Zn
  • Sample 2006-10 - 0.13 g/t Au, 22.8 g/t Ag, 1.31% Cu, 0.20% Zn
  • Sample 2006-11 - 0.19 g/t Au, 11.2 g/t Ag, 0.65% Cu
  • Sample 2007-8 - 2.10 g/t Ag, 0.12% Cu

McIntyre Showing #5

This showing represents a parallel zone of mineralization which is stratigraphically below the mineralized horizon at the #4 showing.  Prospecting by C. Von Klein in 1963, approx. 50 meters north and 75 meters west of the #4 showing returned values up to 5.4% Cu.  The host rock of the showing is a fine-grained mafic volcanic with banded sulphides up to 20% pyrite and 5% chalcopyrite.  It is a prominent gossan in the field.  Recent assays from this showing have returned 0.14% copper (2005-6) and 0.38% copper (2005-7) respectively.

McIntyre Showing #2

The host rock is a gabbro and is a prominent gossan.  In the vicinity of the showing the gabbro appears to be quite narrow and is sandwiched between the Lunny Lake Porphyry to the north and a sedimentary unit to the south.  The Musher Lake Pluton lies about 100 meters south of the showing.  Sampling from 2007 was as follows:

  • Sample 2007-5 - 8.5 g/t Ag, 0.08% Co, 0.11% Cr, 0.53% Cu, 0.45% Ni, 0.06 g/t Pt, 0.07 g/t Pd
  • Sample 2007-6 (re-assay) - 144.0 g/t Ag, 0.10% Cr, 0.76% Cu, 0.19% Ni, 0.54% Pb, 0.81% Zn, 0.04 g/t Pt, 0.05 g/t Pd
  • Sample 2007-16 - 65.9 g/t Ag, 0.12% Cr, 0.43% Cu, 0.69% Ni, 0.11 g/t Pt, 0.13 g/t Pd

A gold soil anomaly lies immediately southwest of the showing.  In addition, there is a highly altered sericite schist – referred to as the Lunny Lake Porphyry - adjacent the gabbro.  A strong EM conductor overlies this mineralization.

McIntyre Zone C

This zone is a VLF Conductor striking 100°.  The rocks here are sheared mafic volcanics that contain appreciable amounts of sericite and lesser carbonate and minor quartz veining.  Amounts of 2-3% py and po are present with minor cpy.  Sections of the zone are strongly magnetic.  Assays from this area include:

  • Sample 2005-1 - 09 g/t gold and 1.5 g/t silver
  • Sample 2005-2 - 0.10 g/t gold
  • Sample 2005-3 - 0.13% zinc

Noranda Trench 197E

This trench located about 300 meters east of the #2 showing.  The trench has stripped a section of the Lunny Lake Porphyry and mixed sediments.  If the gabbro extends east from the #2 showing into this area, then it is presumed to be immediately south of the trenching.  A grab sample of the mineralized sediments from this trench, containing 2-3% pyrite, returned 0.21% Zn (sample 2006-5).

Road Zone

Gold was found in the roadbed of the access road into the area.  Several rusty, localized pieces of float make up this section of the roadbed.  A large boulder immediately west of the road is similar in composition.  The rocks appear to be a sedimentary iron formation containing up to 30% pyrite +/- magnetite and moderate carbonate and chlorite alteration.  While the bedrock source was not found, it is apparent that the float has been transported from an area very close by.  Further, there is also a very strong EM conductor immediately south of the sample, which is the likely source of the sample.  Overburden in the area does not allow for good outcrop exposure and trenching is highly recommended at this locale to find this promising rock unit.  A sample from the roadbed sample assayed 2.40 g/t Au and 5.4 g/t Ag (sample 2007-2).

Lunny Lake Porphyry

The porphyry grades into a ‘feldspathic unit’ in the south-eastern part of the property.  Drilling by Hemlo Gold in 1996 encountered 1 meter of 37.4 g/t Au just 100 meters from the property boundary.  A second drill hole, 200 meters further east, encountered 3 meters of 3.9 g/t Au, including 1 meter of 10.6 g/t Au.  The porphyry is 100-150 meters wide and strikes across the entire property a distance of four kilometres.

Summary

Of great interest is a quartz-eye porphyry known as the Lunny Lake Porphyry which contains appreciable amounts of sulphides.  The hanging wall of the Lunny Lake Porphyry seems to offer good potential for ore-grade mineralization, and further sampling along this horizon is warranted.  In addition, the McIntyre Showing #2 wasn’t re-located until 2007 and based upon sampling to date, has very good potential to host ore-grade mineralization.  Sampling has returned assays of 179.0 g/t silver, 0.12% chromium, 0.76% copper, 0.69% nickel, 0.08% cobalt, 0.11 g/t platinum, 0.13 g/t palladium 0.54% lead and 0.81% zinc.  Little is known about the zone's orientation or width/strike potential and consequently it is a very high priority target.  Due to the strong similarity to the porphyritic rocks at Hemlo and

name: Black River
description: The property hosts a high-grade Zn-Pb-Ag occurrence.  A grab sample collected by a prospector from the occurrence in 1991 returned assay values of 10.7% Zn, 8.9% Pb and 77.8 g/t Ag.  The occurrence has only seen 6 shallow holes (Cominco, 1965) and assay results were not reported.
body:
Location and Access

The Black River property consists of 45 claim units located in the Wabikoba Lake area of the Thunder Bay Mining District.  The claims are located approximately 10 km northwest of the Hemlo gold deposit and can be accessed from two directions.  The western portion of the property can be reached by travelling 24 km down the Swede Lake forest access road, which turns off Highway 614 approximately 26 km south of the town of Manitouwadge.  The eastern portion of the property can be reached by traveling north on Highway 614 from the Trans-Canada highway a distance of 14 kilometers.  From that point, the Amwri Lake road runs westerly roughly 5 kilometers to the property.  The Amrwi Lake road, however, has not been kept up and is limited to ATV or 4X4 vehicle traffic.  An alternate route would be to travel a further 6 kilometers north to the Pinegrove Lake road, which is in much better shape.  Heading south a distance of 8 kilometers will bring you to the property.

Geology

The property is located within the Archean Schreiber-Hemlo Greenstone Belt that is part of the Abitibi-Wawa-Shebandowan Subprovince of the Superior Province.  More specifically, it is situated on the western end of the north limb of the Hemlo synform and is dominated by south-west/north-east striking sequences of metavolcanic and metasedimentary rocks bounded to the north by the Gowan Lake Pluton. The supracrustal rocks consist principally of tholeiitic basaltic flows and subordinate turfs, intercalated with epiclastic arkosic wacke and siltstone. Feldspar porphyry dykes and sills intrude both volcanics and sediments.

Reconnaissance geological mapping was conducted in 1964 and 1965 (Milne, 1968) at 1:31680. The only other work recorded is in 1984 (Kemp, 1984) at 1:5000 and in 1988 (Hamilton, 1989) at 1:5000. From compiling assessment work data, the property can be shown to be underlain by a package of volcanic and sedimentary rocks.  From the monzonite contact southward, a thin, less than 150 meter section, of foliated mafic volcanics is in sharp contact with mudstones which are in contact with a thin felsic pyroclastic unit which grades into laminated sediments and conglomerates. The Kusins Occurrence (discussed in detail below) occurs at the contact of the mudstones and the felsic tuffs.  The property is truncated in the south by the Bullring Lake Fault.

Previous Exploration

1964: Prospecting, stripping and trenching; prospectors W. Kusins and G. Ihnatko. This work exposed Zn-, Pb- and Ag-bearing sulphide mineralization.

1965: Line cutting, ground geophysical and soil geochemical surveys, diamond drilling (6 shallow holes); Cominco. Geological mapping; ODM (V.G. Milne).

1966: trenching; prospectors W. Kusins

1978-1979: Lake sediment and water geochemical sampling; GSC and MNR. Samples collected from the vicinity of the occurrence contained slightly anomalous amounts of Cu, Zn and Pb.

1983: Line cutting, ground geophysical (MAG) and soil geochemical surveys; Noranda Exploration Co., Ltd. Airborne geophysical survey (HLEM, VLF-EM, MAG); Aerodat Ltd.

1984: Geological mapping and litho-geochemical sampling; Noranda Exploration Co., Ltd.

1988: Geological mapping and soil geochemical sampling; Dolphin Explorations Ltd.
