1989: Dighem airborne geophysical survey; Noranda Exploration Co., Ltd. and Noranda Minerals Inc. (Geco Division).

1991: Reconnaissance till sampling; GSC (I.M. Kettles). Litho-geochemical sampling; OGS (D. B. McKay).

1991-1992: Line cutting, stripping, trenching, litho-geochemical sampling, geological mapping and ground geophysical surveys (MAG, VLF-EM, Beep Mat); D. Saunders and P. Simoneau.

1994-1996: Line cutting, MAG survey, prospecting; B. Fowler

2003-2005: Line cutting, MAG/VLF survey, prospecting; B. Fowler

2010: Line cutting, MAG/VLF survey, prospecting; B. Fowler

2012: Soil sampling; Entourage Metals

Property Mineralization (Kusins Occurrence)

The Kusins occurrence is located within the Wawa Subprovince along the north limb of the Schreiber-Hemlo greenstone belt approximately 10 km north of the Hemlo mining camp. The supracrustral rocks in the vicinity of the occurrence are moderately to strongly foliated (235° strike and 60° NW dip) and have experienced upper amphibolite facies-grade regional metamorphism (Milne 1968, Simoneau 1992). The occurrence is underlain primarily by a northeast-trending sequence of foliated, amphibolitic, mafic metavolcanic schists and gneisses; siliceous, argillaceous metasedimentary rocks; and sericitic, felsic metavolcanic tuffs (Milne 1966, 1968; Kemp 1984; Hamilton 1989; Simoneau 1992). The occurrence is located on the northwest side of a low ridge at the contact between the argillaceous metasedimentary rocks and the felsic metavolcanic tuffs (Simoneau 1992). The Gowan Lake and Cedar Lake plutons are located approximately 225 m northwest and 3 km southeast of the occurrence, respectively (Milne 1966; Milne 1968, Map 2144). In the vicinity of the occurrence, the supracrustal rocks proximal to the contact with the Gowan Lake Pluton have been brecciated (Simoneau 1992). The Bullring Lake Fault, a major west-northwest trending dextral fault, is located approximately 305 m south of the occurrence (Milne 1968; Simoneau 1992). Several Proterozoic diabase dikes have intruded the supracrustral rocks in the vicinity of the occurrence. Six pits, varying in size up to approximately 7 m long by 2 m wide by 2.5 m deep have been blasted into the occurrence. These pits are largely rubble-filled and overgrown by vegetation. Pits 1 to 3 are located primarily within theargillaceous metasediments while pits 4 to 6 are primarily within the felsic metavolcanic tuffs. Sulphides are exposed in all of the pits.  The argillaceous metasediments are generally fine-grained, dark to light gray, thinly laminated, siliceous phyllites and schists. The felsic metavolcanic tuffs are generally fine- to medium-grained, light tan to buff, thinly laminated, quartz-phyric, quartzofeldspathic sericite schists. The main mineralized zone is hosted within the argillaceous metasediments.  The sulphides consist primarily of fine- to coarse-grained, generally euhedral pyrite with minor amounts of fine- to medium-grained, dark brown, anhedral sphalerite, coarse-grained, euhedral galena and rare, medium-grained, anhedral chalcopyrite. The sulphides, exposed in pits 1 to 3, define a mineralized zone approximately 3 m wide and 15 m long which parallels the foliation of the surrounding rocks.  Disseminated pyrite occurs throughout this zone. Two thin (30 cm wide), foliation-parallel seams, composed primarily of semi-massive to massive pyrite, occur within the central portion of this mineralized zone. Some of the sulphides display evidence of having undergone recrystallization and remobilization. The coarse-grained pyrite in the central portion of the mineralized zone often displays an annealed texture. Narrow (1 to 2 mm wide) veinlets of fine-grained sphalerite containing minor galena crosscut the semi-massive sulphide zone exposed in pit 2. Thin seams (3 mm wide) of massive pyrite crosscut wider, pyrite-rich sulphide seams exposed in pit 3. These crosscutting pyrite seams parallel a major joint direction (295°) in the surrounding host rocks (Milne 1968). Galena and sphalerite were only observed in pits 2 and 3. The galena was often associated with narrow, crosscutting, calcite-rich, quartz-carbonate veins within the central portion of the mineralized zone. Grab samples collected from the occurrence in 1991 by D.B. McKay for the OGS returned assay values which varied from nil to 0.024 ounce Au/ton, nil to 0.20 ounce Ag/ton, 0.003 to 0.022% Cu, 0.002 to 3.822% Zn and <0.001 to 1.512% Pb. A grab sample collected by prospector P. Simoneau in 1991 returned assay values of 10.7% Zn, 8.9% Pb and 2.5 ounce Ag/ton. A 0.80 m long chip sample collected by the same prospector is reported to have contained 0.84% Zn, 0.13% Pb and 1.8 ounce Ag/ton.

Past Drilling

Mining Corp of Canada (1964)

MC-1 (107 m)

MC-2 (151 m)

MC-4 (47 m)

Cominco (1965)

Six shallow holes; no assessment record.

Newmont (1982)

SL-2 (360 m)

Noranda/Pryme Energy (1983)

PN-4 (212 m) - intersected 0.9 m @ 1.1% Cu, 0.9% Zn (194.1-195.0)

Battle Mountain (1996)

P96-1 (206 m)

P96-2 (220 m)

P96-3 (205 m)

Conclusions

The property hosts a high-grade Zn-Pb-Ag occurrence discovered by W. Kusins in 1963.  A grab sample from the occurrence collected by prospector P. Simoneau in 1991 returned assay values of 10.7% Zn, 8.9% Pb and 77.8 g/t Ag.  The showing has only seen 6 shallow holes in 1965 by Cominco and assay results were not reported.  The mineralized unit from the showing east to the Black River (a distance of 1,200 meters) has never been drilled and represents a significant target for VMS-style mineralization.

A second very important target on the property lies in the north-east part of the property covering an intense mag anomaly.  The anomaly appears to have been drilled by Mining Corp of Canada in 1964 with three short holes.  Again, there is no record of their assessment or drill assays.  Sampling by B. Fowler in 2003 uncovered highly silicified and carbonated intermediate-felsic volcanic rock containing abundant pyrite within the high mag anomaly.  A short distance to the northeast, this unit carries high gold in soil (Entourage, 2012).  It is suspected that the adjacent Black-Pic Batholith provided a felsic magma heat source for a potential gold zone along this trend.  Adding further reinforcement to the potential of this unit, is the discovery of gold-bearing float by prospector Mick Stares in 1994 some 3 kilometres southwest of the property. The sample of float, described as mafic volcanic containing 20% pyrite, assayed 16.2 g/t gold.  The mafic unit is stratigraphically above the zinc-bearing horizon; adjacent to the Gowan Lake (monzonite) Pluton; and along strike of the high mag anomaly to the northeast.  The source for this float has not been found.

As a result, two prominent targets exist within the four kilometre long Black River Property.

name: Valley Lake
description: The Valley Lake property covers a 2 kilometer strike length of a mafic volcanic unit, which is presumed to be the host of high grade gold float assaying 16.2 grams/tonne gold found just 450 meters southwest of the property.
body:
Location and Access

The Valley Lake property consists of 10 claim units located in the Wabikoba Lake area of the Thunder Bay Mining District.  The claims are located approximately 10 km northwest of the Hemlo gold deposit and can be accessed by travelling 24 km down the Swede Lake forest access road, which turns off Highway 614 approximately 26 km south of the town of Manitouwadge. 

Regional Geology

The property is located within the Archean Schreiber-Hemlo Greenstone Belt that is part of the Abitibi-Wawa-Shebandowan Subprovince of the Superior Province.  More specifically, it is situated on the western end of the north limb of the Hemlo synform and is dominated by south-west/north-east striking sequences of metavolcanic and metasedimentary rocks bounded to the north by the Gowan Lake Pluton. The supracrustal rocks consist principally of tholeiitic basaltic flows and subordinate turfs, intercalated with epiclastic arkosic wacke and siltstone. Feldspar porphyry dykes and sills intrude both volcanics and sediments.

Property Geology

The property is underlain by monzonite and a package of volcanic and sedimentary rocks.  From the monzonite contact southward, a 150 meter wide section, of foliated mafic volcanics is in sharp contact with mudstones which are in contact with a thin felsic pyroclastic unit which grades into laminated sediments and conglomerates. The adjacent Kusins Occurrence occurs at the contact of the mudstones and the felsic tuffs.  The property is crosscut by diabase dykes.

Previous Exploration

The property covers the western portion of a pyritic, silicified sericite horizon that hosts the high-grade Kusins occurrence (10.7% zinc, 8.9% lead and 77.8 grams/ton silver) which W.T. Kusins discovered in 1962.  Kusins put down four small pits on the occurrence in 1964 before he optioned his claims to Cominco in 1965 who drilled 6 shallow holes on the occurrence in 1965.

In 1994, Mick Stares, a prospector from Thunder Bay, found a piece of float that assayed 16.2 g/t gold in a mafic volcanic unit containing 20% pyrite.  Stares float was taken just 450 meters west of the Valley Lake property.  The source for the float wasn’t found.

In 1995, Battle Mountain Canada drilled three holes in the immediate area.  Two of these holes (V95-1 and V95-2) were collared south-west of the property and one hole (V95-3) was collared south of the property.  All three holes tested I.P. chargeability anomalies.

In 1996, Battle Mountain Canada drilled two more holes in the area.  The diamond drilling tested the horizon that hosts the Kusins occurrence as well as two separate I.P. chargeability anomalies situated on either side of this horizon.  One of these holes (OR96-1) was collared east of the property, while OR96-2 drilled a section of sediments in the extreme east part of the property.  The sediments in hole OR96-1 displayed moderate to strong pervasive and fracture-controlled silicification and feldspathization as well as local disseminations of molybdenum.  In addition the unit displayed up to 3% quartz-eyes, weak pervasive sericite alteration and are associated with a zone of intense fracturing and brecciation.

Drill hole OR96-2 was drilled 550m west-south-west of OR96-1 and was designed as a stratigraphic hole to test the "felsic" horizon as well as an IP chargeability anomaly located along strike of the northern-most IP conductor tested in OR96-1.  The hole collared in fine grained, well laminated, biotite-rich sediments (argillite, siltstone).  Altered sediments with 5% disseminated pyrrhotite +/- Pyrite (similar to those intersected in OR96-1) were cored.

Both holes were drilled south of the mafic volcanic unit of interest.

Conclusions

The gold float (16.2 g/t) found by M. Stares on the property suggests that the mafic volcanics which overlie the zinc-bearing, felsic horizon and underlie the Gowan Lake Pluton, may be enriched in gold.  Prospecting by Simoneau in 1993 in an area 150 meters north of the Zn, Pb, Ag Occurrence showed a brecciated intrusive texture at the contact with foliated mafic rocks and the Gowan Lake (monzonite) Pluton. Volcaniclastic metasediments along the margin of the Gowan Lake Pluton to the west also show signs of hydrothermal alteration, both visually and geochemically, and bear similarities to the metasediments which host the Hemlo deposit.  This may be a widespread feature and could be significant. 

Two electromagnetic conductors exist northeast (up ice) of the high-grade gold float (OGS Map M60036/37).  The first EM conductor lies 600 meters northeast of the float sample and appears to have an East-West strike length of 500 meters.  The second EM conductor lies 250 meters north of the first and shows a similar East-West strike of 400 meters.  These two conductors lie very close to the monzonite/volcanic contact.  The contact between the monzonite and underlying mafic volcanic unit has never been mapped in detail.  The area surrounding the two conductors should be mapped and sampled in detail in an effort to locate the source of the gold float.

The Valley Lake property covers 2 kilometers of favourable geology along the Gowan Lake Pluton and Mafic Volcanic contact.  The property has the potential to host a potentially economic gold deposit.

name: Santoy Mountain
description: A quartz stockwork in strongly altered granite-monzonite porphyry contains up to 46.9 g/t Au, 422 g/t Ag and 5.4% Cu beside the Santoy Lake property.  Additionally, a float sample assaying an astounding 66% zinc has been located in the vicinity of Little Santoy Lake.
body:
Introduction

The Santoy Mountain property consists of two claims (15 units) in Syine Township of the Thunder Bay Mining Division.  The property is situated approximately 20 km east of Terrace Bay, Ontario and lies east of Jackfish Bay, Lake Superior.  The claims may be accessed by the Trans-Canada highway, which cuts through the western part of the property.  A well-kept gravel road that leads to Santoy Lake provides access to the eastern part of the property.

The property straddles a section of the easternmost Terrace Bay batholith/mafic volcanic contact.  This contact has numerous gold zones associated with it, the most notable being the Empress Gold Mine, a former producer, discovered in 1895.  Other past producing mines exist on the western end of the batholith/volcanic contact near the town of Schreiber.  Gold showings lie within both the felsic stock and the adjacent volcanic rocks.

Previous Work

Gold was first discovered in the Jackfish Lake area in 1875 when Mr. D. McKellar found visible gold in a quartz vein at Victoria Cape. Subsequent activity in the area resulted in the discovery of the Empress Mine north of Jackfish Lake in 1895 and the Ursa Major Mine 3 km north of the Empress.  There is also mention of a gold occurrence south of Jackfish Station (old Jackfish town site) just south of the granite/volcanic contact (Schreiber-Duck Lake Area, ODM volume 30, part 4, 1921).  In the late 1950's, 1960's, and 1970's various companies reportedly carried out exploration for base metals. 

In 1983 the area became staked again due to the discovery of the Hemlo deposit.  Highmark Resources and MacMillan Energy formed a joint venture to explore ground that makes up the current property.  The joint venture performed geochemical, geological and geophysical surveys.  Some astonishingly high soil anomalies coincident with VLF and IP conductors were uncovered, but remarkably, they were never drilled.

In 1993, Brian Fowler acquired the property and performed prospecting and sampling.  He took three samples, one of which returned 62.2 g/t silver (assay report dated Aug. 25th, 1993, sample #93-43) from an area about 100 meters west of the Santoy Mountain Occurrence.

In 1995, Rudy Wahl prospected the same area as Fowler, and collected several samples, the best of which assayed anomalous zinc and nickel (4,360 ppm Zn, 484 ppm Ni).

In 2009, Fowler returned to the area to cut a single 975m grid line striking approximately 334° from the access road alongside Little Santoy Lake north to the Santoy Mountain Occurrence.  A magnetic and VLF EM survey was performed by Larder Geophysics using a GSM-19 v7 Overhauser magnetometer.

Geology

The property is located within the Schreiber-Hemlo greenstone belt and represents a portion of the Abitibi-Wawa subprovince of the Superior province. This subprovince is an east-west trending metavolcanic - metasedimentary supracrustal sequence which has been intruded by granitic/syenitic plutons and gabbroic dikes and sills.

The geology of the property consists mainly of mafic volcanic rock which is most commonly massive to pillowed (tops south) with minor foliated, lineated equivalents. To the north, this greenstone belt is bounded by massive hornblende-(biotite) granodiorite and granite, quartz monzonite.  Highmark reported that Irregular lenses of intermediate to felsic volcanics are present in three separate zones. These are associated with mineralization.  Two areas are also underlain by bedded chert, argillite and greywacke. These rocks also contain sulfide mineralization.  Other rocks in the area include minor lapilli tuff, schist, breccia and various compositions of dykes.  The rocks generally strike N70°E.

Mineralization

The intermediate to felsic volcanics present in the northern part of the property are associated with narrow chert horizons containing massive pyrite mineralization.  A showing termed the “Santoy Mountain Occurrence” reportedly contains small amounts of copper and nickel and lies south of one of these cherty units.  A rock grab sample collected by Brian Fowler in 1993, one hundred metres west of the occurrence returned 62.2 g/t silver.  In 2009, Fowler collected an additional 11 samples across a 300-meter section of rocks straddling the Santoy Mountain Occurrence.  Between 600W and 650W of the grid, Fowler found sheared, rusty mafic volcanic rocks containing appreciable amounts (up to 30%) of pyrite and pyhrrotite.  He noted a sedimentary iron formation at the 690W grid coordinate, and more pyritiferous mafic volcanics at 800W and 900W.  One sample of mafic volcanic containing 20-30% pyrite and appreciable chlorite alteration returned 1040 ppm chromium.  Minor base metals were reported (271ppm Cu and 259ppm Zn).

Conclusions

The Santoy Mountain occurrence, as well as the chert rich horizons in the vicinity of the occurrence require detailed mapping and sampling in light of the high nickel (323ppm) and zinc (823ppm) values from lake sediment in the small pond north of Little Santoy Lake.  The OGS sampling represents the highest nickel and third highest zinc assay in the survey area, from a total of 1,176 samples taken (Schreiber-Terrace Bay High Density Regional Lake Sediment and Water Survey, OFR 5964). 

Highmark’s 1983 soil survey (2,200 soil samples) uncovered three highly anomalous areas (Anomaly A, B and C) north of the pond that the OGS found high nickel and zinc values in.  Anomaly A lies within the northern portion of the Santoy Lake property, while anomalies B and C are immediately north of the property on adjacent ground owned by Renner and Richards.

Anomaly A - a 100 meter long by 125 meter wide anomaly from L11300E to L11400E between 10350N and 10475N.  The anomaly contains up to 920 ppm zinc, 479 ppm copper and 9,000 ppm lead in soil.  A moly showing reportedly occurs at the east end of the anomaly.  Highmark indicates a pit in this vicinity, so it is believed that the moly values came from this pit.

Anomaly B - a single line anomaly at L11200E at 10725N, containing a remarkably highly cobalt value of 5,000 ppm.

Anomaly C - a 100 meter long anomaly from L11300E to L11400E at 10625N contains up to 4.2 g/t silver in the soil.

Two hundred meters to the west of the spectacular lead soil value (9,015 ppm) lies an outcrop of massive pyrite and chert.  The section of rocks between the mineralized chert outcrop and the high lead-in-soil ranks as a high priority target.

Adding further fuel to the fire, are recent discoveries of high-grade gold, silver and base metals adjacent the property.  Prospecting by Wayne Richards immediately north of the Santoy Mountain property has uncovered a quartz stockwork in strongly altered granite-monzonite porphyry.  The quartz veins contain tourmaline, chlorite, hematite, olivine and carbonate alteration.  Assays range up to 46.9 g/t Au, 422 g/t Ag and 5.4% Cu.  Additionally, prospecting by Rudy Wahl, in the vicinity of Little Santoy Lake, uncovered a float sample that assayed an astounding 66% zinc.  The source for the float is suspected to be near the cherty iron formations in the northern portion of the Santoy Mountain property. 

As a result of these recent findings, the Santoy Mountain property has high potential for both gold and VMS discoveries.

name: Dotted Lake
description: Owned by Rouge Resources, this large property covers 9 kilometers of highly favourable geology that encompasses a significant high grade gold discovery.  The host rock is sheared granitoid rock with 5-10% pyrite, strong sericite and arsenopyrite.
body:
Location

Rouge Resources Dotted Lake property lies just north of the world class 21 million ounce Hemlo gold deposit currently being mined by Barrick Gold Corp.  The property is located 45 km south of Manitouwadge and 20 km north of the Hemlo Gold Mines.  Drivable logging roads are within 1km of the property.

Geology

The Dotted Lake property is chiefly underlain by mafic massive and pillowed volcanics and related subvolcanic phases. The mafic rocks are intruded by granitic and diabase intrusives. The diabases are north-south and northwest-southeast trending, with both orientations of dyke forming steep cliffs.  The eastern portion of the claims contain a mafic and ultramafic intrusive complex of peridotite and serpentinized peridotite intruded along the southern flank of the mafic volcanics.

Granitic gneisses mark the north margin of the volcanic belt and extend north to the Manitouwadge area some 30 kilometers to the north.  The general metamorphic grade throughout the map area is upper greenschist to lower amphibolite, which is typical of the volcanics of the Heron Bay-Hemlo belt.

Mineralization

The Dotted Lake property covers a 9 kilometer strike length of highly-favourable rocks that host the Fairservice zinc occurrence.  Grab samples taken from the occurrence by previous operators have assayed up to 12% zinc and 2.18 g/t gold.  The occurrence consists of disseminated to semi-massive sphalerite, pyrite and magnetite in a zone up to 50 centimeters wide by 10 meters long within foliated hornblende amphibolite and banded garnet, biotite, chlorite and muscovite gneiss.  Such rocks may represent metamorphism of a small, distal volcanogenic, massive sulfide deposit similar to the past producing Geco Mine in Manitouwadge.

In 2008, Rouge conducted a modest soil sampling program on the property and noted anomalous zinc with coincident significant gold (up to .48 g/t Au) anomalies approximately 800 meters south of the Fairservice zinc occurrence.  Further work was recommended to expand on the anomaly.

In 2009, local prospectors returned a value of 2.33 g/t gold in strongly sheared mafic volcanics with intense biotite alteration containing 3-5% pyrite on the Rouge Resources Lampson Lake Option.  The sample lies at the contact between mafic volcanics and sediments.  The footwall sediments are metamorphosed to sericite schist and contain narrow bands of biotite and 1% pyrite.  The gold sample lies along a shear which is a splay off a major NE trending fault that may play a major role in the mineralization at the Fairservice zinc occurrence.

In 2009, Rouge conducted additional soil sampling in the area of the 2008 sampling and expanded upon the gold signature in the soils.  Some of the better results were:

·         09-1-01 - 484 ppb Au (590797E, 5416951N)

·         09-1-03 - 144 ppb Au (590721E, 5417018N)

·         09-3-29 - 234 ppb Au (590650E, 5416410N)

·         09-4-41 - 1,200 ppm Zn (590579E, 5416197N)

In 2010, Rouge conducted a small trenching program in the vicinity of the high gold in soils.  High grade gold was discovered in bedrock exposed by the trenching.

·         I920008 - 16.95 g/t Au (grab) in Trench 10-4

·         I920009 - 686 ppb Au (grab) in Trench 10-4

·         H073926 - 9.02 g/t Au over 0.4 m (channel) in Trench 10-4

·         H073934 - 1.14 g/t Au over 1.0 m (channel) in Trench 10-4

This high-grade gold zone consists of sheared granitoid rock with 5-10% pyrite, strong sericite and a trace of arsenopyrite.

Summary

There are two high priority targets that exist within the Dotted Lake property.  Most notably, is the high grade gold (16.95 g/t Au) found in bedrock during the 2010 trenching program.  This relatively new discovery has never been drilled and shows great promise.

A second high priority target exists within the property for a significant VMS deposit.  The magnetic pattern of the rocks within the property boundary suggest that this may be the northern limb of a large folded structure similar to the one at Manitouwadge.  An isolated anomaly, annular in shape, under Lampson Lake suggests it is a possible synvolcanic mafic intrusive and would be a heat source for base metal development.  An extremely high copper value (985 ppm) in the lake sediment of Lampson Lake (OGS Open File Report 5968) exists on the Lampson Lake Option.  This may indicate a bedrock source of copper mineralization under, or along the lake edge.  It represents the second highest copper value within the Government funded survey.  The highest copper value in the survey area is at Bamoos Lake; now the site of Marathon PGM Corp’s 90 million tonne PGE, Cu, Ag and Au deposit outside the town of Marathon.

Finally, a third target exists for potential PGE mineralization within the ultramafic intrusive complex of peridotite and serpentinized peridotite.

In light of the recent high-grade gold discovery and the suggestive potential for both VMS and PGE mineralization, the Dotted Lake property is one of the most exciting grassroots plays in the Hemlo greenstone belt.

name: Bozema Lake
description: The 154-unit Bozema Lake Property contains a potassium radiometric anomaly with sodium depletion, that extends for over 6 kilometers through the property. The alteration zone bears similarities, geologically and geochemically, to the Hemlo gold deposit some 100 kilometers to the east.
body:
Location and Access

The Bozema Lake property, comprising of 154 claim units, is approximately 225 kilometers northeast of Thunder Bay, Ontario.  The TransCanada highway, electrical power lines and the Canadian Pacific Railway lie immediately south of the property. The claims are located between the towns of Terrace Bay and Marathon which can provide all supplies and manpower needed for exploration and development. Marathon is situated on a deep water port on Lake Superior.

Regional Geology

The property lies within the Schreiber-Hemlo greenstone belt and represents a portion of the Abitibi-Wawa Subprovince of the Superior Province. The Abitibi-Wawa Subprovince is a supracrustal east-west trending metavolcanic-metasedimentary sequence which has been intrude by granite-syenitic plutons and metagabbroic dikes and sills. The belt hosts the Hemlo gold deposit approximately 100 kilometers to the east and the Winston Lake base metal mine 55 kilometers to the west.  The Schreiber portion of the belt is approximately 70 kilometers long and 25 kilometers wide. The western portion of the belt is composed of two limbs, separated by the Crossman Lake Batholith, which form an east-west trending anticline. The northern limb, the Big Duck Lake volcanic belt is approximately 35 kilometers long and 10 kilometers wide, while the southern limb is approximately 50 kilometers long and 10 kilometers wide. The property is situated in the southern limb of the belt.

Property Geology

The geology of the property is characterized by east trending, intermediate to felsic pyroclastics, flows and tuffs, bounded to the south by metabasalts and granite to the north. Much of the property was mapped at reconnaissance scale during the spring and summer of 1996 (Clark, 1996; Needham, 1996). These mapping programs explored a potassium radiometric anomaly brought to attention by Shevchenco, Placer Dome Canada (1996). The anomaly is approximately 6 kilometers long and up to 1 kilometer wide and is characterized by whole rock geochemical data revealing an alteration zone exhibiting two dominant patterns - extensive sodium depletion, accompanied by silica and potassium enrichment, and sodium enrichment coupled with silica enrichment and potassium depletion.

Previous Work

The exploration records for the property contained within the Resident Geologist Assessment files housed in Thunder Bay indicate that exploration has been sporadically completed since 1896. Gold exploration in the area dates back to the late 1900's when the Empress Mine (Syine Township) and Fire Mountain (Tuuri Township) were located. Previous exploration work completed on and near the Bozema Lake property is as follows.

1955: Noranda Mines Ltd. completed a ground electromagnetic survey on a claim block covering Spider Lake within the present claims.

1963: Roman Corp. completed a ground horizontal loop electromagnetic survey on a claim block covering Spider Lake within the present claim block.

1981: Gulf Minerals drilled four holes in the Bozema Lake area.  One of the drill holes (81-33-2-1) intersected 10 meters of 8.6 % Zn, including 4.7 m @16.9 % Zn.

1988: Noranda Exploration Company Ltd. completed a mapping and lithogeochemistry program over a claim block south of Spider Lake. The survey outlined a sodium depletion zone.

1994: Echo Bay Mines Ltd. completed a geological recon program on the property. A total of 477 samples were taken and analyzed for gold. The work was completed on traverses accessed by helicopter or roads.

1995: Clark-Eveleigh Consulting completed a four day prospecting program on the property.  A total of 7 samples were taken for assay.

2002: RJK Minerals drilled two diamond drill holes (S02-2 and 3) highlighting that the Na and Ca in the core was almost totally depleted, indicating a strong alteration system.  The Zn/Pb ratios encountered were similar to those of the Geco deposit located to the northeast and are typical of many VMS deposits in pyroclastic terrains. Silver and gold was also strongly correlated more strongly with Cu than with Zn or Pb. This also is typical of higher temperature VMS systems and indicated that the area drilled is in a classic VMS setting.  The better of the two holes, S0-2, intersected 0.6 meters of 4.2% Zn, 0.46% Cu, 0.27% Pb and 48.1 g/t Ag; and 0.4 meters of 5.0% Zn, 0.16% Cu, 0.28% Pb and 18.1 g/t Ag.

2005: Phoenix Matachewan Mines completed eleven drill holes totalling 1,683 metres targeting two of eleven highly prospective combined geophysical and geochemical targets identified on the property.  Analytical results returned very anomalous, widespread zinc mineralization, peaking at 7% Zn over 1.2 metres (at 121 metres down hole) in DDH PS0507 in an extensive zone of strongly zinc mineralized rock that averaged 0.58 per cent Zn over 39 metres.  In addition, surface geochemical sampling results returned up to 23.5% zinc and 3.1% copper in outcrops.

2006: Phoenix Matachewan Mines contracted Geotech Limited to fly a helicopter-borne time domain electromagnetic geophysical survey over the Steel River Property. Condor Consulting Inc of Lakewood, Colorado was then contracted to process and analyze the VTEM data in order to assist in identifying and prioritizing possible VMS-style drill targets.

2007-2008: Phoenix Matachewan Mines completed a 28-hole, 3000m drill program on their Steel River property. The program was designed as a follow up to a 2005 drilling program, with collar locations in large part being chosen based on additional information obtained since the completion of the previous program. This work included a helicopter-borne EM survey flown by Geotech Limited, additional mapping by Blackburn Geological Services, and a small amount of stripping on grid 1W – all completed in 2006.  Work focused on the same two primary targets as were drilled in 2005.  The first target area, located on PMM’s grid 3, is an area of approximately 1.63km by 0.77km which covers Bozema Lake.  The second target area, PMM’s grid 1W, is an area of approximately 1.97km by 1.90km, west of the Prairie River.  Zinc assays from the 2005 drill program peaked at 7.0% over 0.6m (DDH PS0507 at 120m depth).  Results from the 2007-2008 program included a best intersection of 11.09% Zn over 3.75m (DDH BZW-08-05).

Conclusions

The property is underlain by a package of intermediate to felsic metavolcanics, intruded by a quartz feldspar porphyry, which has been traced for 3 kilometers along strike.  A potassium radiometric anomaly with sodium depletion, extends for over 6 kilometers through the property. The alteration zone bears similarities, geologically and geochemically, to the Hemlo gold deposit some 100 kilometers to the east (Shevchenco, Placer Dome, 1996).  The property hosts a package of intermediate to felsic metavolcanics which is up to 3 kilometers thick. The presence of course felsic fragments suggests a proximity to a felsic volcanic center.  The presence of a major quartz feldspar porphyry, itself sodium depleted, adds to the interpretation of the proximity of a volcanic center.  The zone of alteration is widespread and characterized by sodium depletion, potassium and silica enrichment, as well as zones of potassium depletion and sodium enrichment or depletion.  Sericite is a common alteration product locally occupying 15% of rock volume.  Many felsic rocks contain blue quartz eyes suggesting metasomatic silica.  Whole rock geochemical data indicates the strongest alteration, in terms of sodium depletion and silica enrichment is spatially associated with the boundaries of the quartz feldspar porphyry. This zone also hosts a relative abundance of felsic agglomerate. These factors would suggest that the quartz feldspar porphyry represents a focal point of hydrothermal alteration and mineralization.  In addition, there are a number of EM conductors associated with the northern contact of the quartz feldspar. These conductors are coincident with the zone of strong sodium depletion and silica enrichment.  These features make the Bozema Lake property an attractive exploration target.

name: Rushing River
description: The 39-unit Rushing River property is host to six gold occurrences, including four shafts (Medicine Ledge, Master Jack, Sunrise and Golden Gate North).  The lateral and vertical continuity of the known gold-bearing structures on the property should be tested.
body:
Location and Access

The property is located 20 kilometers southeast of the town of Kenora, Ontario. Road access to the property from Kenora is eastward via Highway 17 (Trans-Canada Highway) to the Storm Bay road approximately 12 kilometers east of Kenora, then south along the partly paved, partly gravelled Storm Bay road for 12 kilometers. A relatively new road (Blindfold Lake Road) which can be described as a graded, gravelled bush road branches from the east side of the Storm Bay road through the south-central part of the property.  This road is suitable for automobiles travelling at slow speed.

Bedrock topography is typical of that of most of the southern part of the Canadian Shield. Bedrock relief is seldom more than one hundred and fifty feet with rounded knobby hills. The bedrock is commonly covered by sand, silt, gravel, or clay but bedrock outcrops in many places and much of the overburden is only a few feet deep. Much of the area in the south-east part of the property has been cleared by recent lumbering operations.  Elsewhere, the claims are timbered except for low areas which consist of swamps or small lakes.

Previous Activity

The Lake of the Woods Gold Rush occurred between 1886 and 1906.  A large number of gold discoveries were made and 13 properties were brought into production accounting for 75% of the gold produced in the Kenora-Fort Frances District.  By 1912 almost all activities had ceased.  During the period 1934-1943 a second major period of activity in the area.  Activity in the claim area is as follows:

• 1885-1899 - Several companies were involved in mining in this early period.

• 1934 - Johnson-Nilson Group – prospecting

• 1936 - Blindfold Mining Group - trenching, stripping and sampling.  Golden Gate Shaft dewatered and sampled.

• 1983 - George Zebruck and Ted Hansen - prospecting and sampling

• 1983-1984 - Bonzano Exploration - geophysical and geological surveys

• 1985-1986 - Kidd Creek Mines - airborne geophysical and geological surveys

• 1987 - Core Exploration - property evaluation, geological survey

• 1988-1990 - George Zebruck - sampling, assays and drilling

Adjacent Mine Activity

At the Black Jack Prospect, a bulk sample of 50 tons was shipped in 1893, producing 16.5 ounces of gold, for a grade of 0.33 oz Au/ton.  Underground development continued until 1899.  The nearby Gold Hill Mine was developed in 1885 and between 1886 and 1893, produced 220 tons yielding 1,089 oz gold for a grade of 4.95 oz Au/ton.  Work continued at the Gold Hill Mine until 1899 when the mill burned down.  Except for one drill hole, which reportedly cut the "Pebble" vein at a depth of 350 feet, and one which cut the "Black Jack" vein at a vertical depth of 300 feet, no systematic drilling of what is now the Gold Hill-Black Jack Property has ever taken place.

Significant Area Production

Six kilometers south-east of the Rushing River Property lies the past producing Wendigo Mine, which between 1900 and 1951 produced 67,423 ounces of gold, 14,762 ounces of silver, and 1,886,246 pounds of copper, making it the largest past producer in the Kenora - Fort Frances area. The old Sultana Mine lies eleven kilometers north-west of the Rushing River Property, which between 1894 and 1906, and in 1949, produced a total of 15,977 ounces of gold.

Geology

The property is underlain by massive and pillowed basaltic flows with textures ranging from fine to medium grained.  The volcanic rocks are generally massive and weakly metamorphosed to the greenschist facies.  Mafic lavas and intrusions are intruded by the bi-lobed Dryberry granodiorite batholith. The contact of the basalt and the southwest portion of the northwest lobe of the batholith lies along the east boundary of the property. The Dryberry batholith is unique in the Kenora (Wabigoon) group of batholiths because it is much more magnetic than other batholiths in the geological sub-province. The Dryberry batholith has a magnetic level approximately 400 gammas higher than the usual relatively non-magnetic batholiths characteristic of the block.  All bedrock formations are Archean in age.  Numerous (44) gold deposits are related spatially to the western portion of the northwest lobe of the batholith.  Almost all of the deposits are within a mile of the basalt-batholith contact.  Thirty-four deposits are within the volcanic rocks and ten within the granodiorite.

Mineralization

The shear zones hosting the gold veins range from a few inches up to fifteen feet wide and have an anastomosing pattern.  Quartz veins are emplaced into the central portions of the shear zones pinching and swelling along strike. Shear directions appear to be sub-vertical suggesting that the veins may have greater vertical than horizontal dimensions.  Gold is almost entirely within the quartz veins.  The gold occurs as free grains or with chalcopyrite within the quartz veins.  Pyrite and pyrrhotite also occur in the quartz veins but do not appear to be correlated with the gold content.

Adjacent Showings

Golden Gate shaft Vein

The vein consists of quartz in a vertical shear which strikes 100° degrees. Four channel samples sawn from the shaft trench, eastward from the shaft at one metre intervals, by Kidd Creek, showed gold assays ranging from O.476 oz. to 1.18 oz. per ton. The average grade and width of the four samples was 0.7l6 oz. per ton across two feet.  The shaft is on a steep hillside with access to the shaft by a trench.

Golden Gate #1 vein (Main trench)

This vein is exposed in a deep trench which angles up a steep hillside. The vein strikes north-easterly and dips 50° to the northwest. Debris in the trench and the steep angle of the trench make accurate observation impossible. The vein is twenty inches wide. Eleven samples were reported by Kidd Creek. Five of the eleven samples assayed more than 1.5 oz, the highest being 8.31 oz per ton gold.  Four other samples were between 0.25 and 0.50 oz per ton gold.

Property Showings

Medicine Ledge Shaft

 The occurrence is located in the northern portion of the property north of the mouth of the Rushing River on the east side of Route Bay. An inclined shaft was sunk to a depth of at least 11.5 m around 1897. The area is underlain by massive, medium to coarse-grained granodiorite of the Dryberry Batholith. It occurs near the western edge of the batholith approximately 400 m east of the contact with west facing mafic flows. The vein occurs on the footwall of a narrow-east-dipping shear. The vein is described by Coleman (1898) as follows: "A vein of white quartz with some pyrites is said to have been traced 1,800 feet (about 550 m) with a strike of about N10°W. Where work was being done it averaged about 6 feet wide, but narrowed to two or three feet at the bottom of the shaft, which was 38 feet deep at an incline of 45°. The hanging wall was well defined, but the footwall was somewhat broken up". No assays are reported.

Master Jack Shaft

The Master Jack Shaft occurs in the central part of the property. In 1897, the Rat Portage Gold Mining Company sank a 33.5 m shaft with 36 m of lateral development. In 1934 the area was included in a claim group staked around the Golden Gate Prospect located just west of Hollow Lake by the Johnson-Nilson Group. This claim group was acquired by the Blindfold Mining Group in 1936. During this period some trenching, stripping and sampling was done.

The area is underlain by fine-grained, west-facing, massive to pillowed mafic flows which have been intruded by medium-grained, weakly foliated, biotite granodiorite of the Dryberry Batholith. The intrusive contact trends northwesterly. The shaft lies in granodiorite about 400 m east of the contact. In the vicinity of the shaft a tectonic foliation strikes 055° and dips vertically. A quartz vein, about 1.5 m wide, is exposed on the north side of the shaft. The vein appears to lie within a north-northeast trending fracture dipping 75° east. Quartz is white to grey coloured and contains minor pyrite along irregular fine fractures. Coleman (1898) reports that the- vein strikes 020° and it was also exposed about 100 m south of the shaft over a width of 0.6 to 1.0 m (2 to 3 feet).  Core Exploration took assays from the Master Jack Shaft area in November 1987 which assayed up to 0.12 oz/t gold and 6.72 oz/ton silver (dump grab).

Golden Gate North

About 300 feet north of the Golden Gate shaft, lenses of quartz appear in an east-west sheared zone that dips 70°S. A pit 20 feet deep shows 3 feet of quartz at one end and chlorite schist at the other end.  A shaft is shown in this area on OGS map P2831.  No assays are reported.

Hollow Lake Occurrence

At the shore of Hollow Lake, a reported quartz vein, 18 inches wide, is exposed in a trench. The quartz is fairly well mineralized in places.  No assays are reported.

Sunrise Shaft

Core Exploration’s work in 1987, shows a showing and shaft dubbed the Sunrise Showing.  A 10 foot wide vein was sampled and assayed up to 0.20 oz/t gold and 0.80 oz/t silver (sample #960).

Magnetic Showing

Core Exploration’s work in 1987 also uncovered an iron formation south of the Sunrise showing which they called the Magnetic Showing.  Sampling of the iron formation assayed as high as 0.62 oz/t silver (sample #8086).

Summary

Gold deposits in the area occur in a cluster in close proximity to the contract of metavolcanics with the Dryberry Batholith, and appear to be related to fracture systems developed as a result of the intrusion of the batholith.  In fact, recent government research suggest that most, if not all of the gold showings in the northeast Lake of the Woods area are directly related to the intrusion of the Dryberry Batholith, and their proximity to it.  It seems likely the hydrothermal systems generated by regional metamorphism related to the intrusion of the Dryberry Batholith are responsible for the transport and deposition of gold.  The property covers in excess of 4 kilometers of this favourable contact.

Recommendations

The lateral and vertical continuity of the known gold-bearing structures on the Rushing River property should be tested.  Systematic mapping of the entire property is a high priority to locate zones of intersection of major gold-bearing structures (i.e., veins and shears), and zones of secondary gold-bearing structures (i.e., vein and stringer systems).  An Induced Polarization survey would be useful for targeting sulphide-bearing zones.  Furthermore, it would be worthwhile to extract a number of bulk samples from the four shaft areas within the property (Medicine Ledge, Master Jack, Sunrise and Golden Gate North) to determine their overall grades and ore recovery.

name: Scramble
description: The 8-unit Scramble property is immediately adjacent the Scramble Mine workings and will host the zone at depth and along strike.
body:
Location and Access

The Scramble Property is located in Jaffray Township, within the City of Kenora, and about eight kilometers east of the downtown, business centre. Access to the Scramble Property is provided by the Jones Road off the Trans-Canada Highway or by the Homestake Road from downtown Kenora.  The property consists of one Crown mining claim totaling 8 units that encompass an area of 320 acres.  The adjacent property, owned by Abitibi- Consolidated, hosts the Scramble Mine Patents.

Geology

The Scramble Property lies within the Archean Lake of the Woods greenstone belt of the Wabigoon Subprovince, Superior Province. Rocks of the greenstone belt range from volcanic basaltic flows to pyroclastic dacite and rhyolite, with associated clastic sediments, and granitic and other plutonic batholith-scale intrusions. During the Kenoran Orogeny the supracrustal rocks were tightly folded and metamorphosed to greenschist and amphibolite grade.  The property straddles a submarine basalt flow sequence within a promontory of the greenstone belt at its northeast edge that tapers towards the northeast. Minor felsic to intermediate tuffaceous rocks occur at the northwest corner of the Scramble Property and also within its southwestern part. Minor felsic dikes are both parallel and cross-cut the dominant north-easterly structural trend.

Property Mineralization

In about 1896 the Electro Gold Mining and Milling Co., Ltd. sunk a shaft within the Scramble Property.  Medium-grained gabbroic rock has been noted in the shaft area, and a felsic sill striking north-easterly lies 10 m to the northwest of the shaft. On surface, there is no evidence of any particular structure or mineralized zone on which the shaft may have been sunk. It is speculated that because of the association of mineralization on the adjacent Scramble property with felsic sills, it is possible that the shaft was sunk in the mafic rock with the intention of cross-cutting to the nearby felsic sill.  Chip and grab samples taken in the shaft have returned assays of 0.7, 1.0 and 1.0 g gold per ton.  The shaft lies along strike and in the same 'time-line' volcanic suite of the Scramble Deposit.

In 1985 and 1986, two diamond drill holes were put down wholly within the present Scramble Property near the Electro Gold Shaft.

Hole #   Year       Az           Dip         Depth (m)

S-5          1985       135°       -45°        148.43

S-42       1986       135°       -45°        142.39

Both holes intersected alternating sequences, predominantly of fine grained basalt and gabbroic mafic flow or subvolcanic rock, and felsic sills. Some sections were also logged as mafic and felsic tuff. Notably, the latter was suggested to be “exhalite” in one of the holes. Quartz-calcite-tourmaline veining, weak biotite alteration, disseminated pyrite and pyrrhotite rarely exceeding a few percent, are characteristic of the basalts.

DDH S-5 one section ran 735 ppb (0.7 g/tonne) gold over 1.3m within a 3m core length termed “exhalite”, all of which ran above trace amounts. Lower in the same hole, a section ran 560 ppb (0.6 g tonne) gold over 1.2m in a 3.4m core length of basalt with quartz-calcite veining.

DDH hole S-42 intersected a 3m wide breccia zone that was interpreted to be a fault and contained ~5% sulphides and trace amounts of gold.

Scramble Mine Patents

Work to date has defined the 1.5 meter wide Scramble zone along a strike length of 700 meters and to a depth of 200 meters.  The zone strikes 45° east and dips 88° north.  Geophysics suggests the zone has a potential strike length of 2 km.  The geological model for the mineralization is a gold-bearing exhalite system (Timmins-Type Gold System).  Gold is concentrated in a north-easterly striking sheared zone in biotitized basalts rather than in conformable felsic dikes and cross cutting quartz veins within the zone.  Close-patterned diamond drilling, surface sampling and underground development work, all conducted in the 1980s by the joint venture partnership of Scramble Mining Ltd. and Madeleine Mines Ltd., led to commissioning of a study (Behre, Dolbear & Company Inc. 1989) that provided an estimate of proven, probable and possible reserves, for a total of 139,000 tons at a grade of 0.24 ounce (8.2 g) gold ton.

Property Potential

Gold mineralization of potential economic grade on the Scramble Zone has to date been amply demonstrated on the adjacent Scramble Mine patented lands, by underground sampling and diamond drilling.  Mineralization on the Scramble Mine patented lands is confined within a northeast trending shear zone within basalts. Coincident with the gold mineralization in the shear zone are linear magnetic anomalies and induced polarization (IP) responses. Any extension of the zone would extend onto the Scramble Property.

It is very significant that a drill hole contained wholly on the Scramble Property intersected a 3m section logged as "exhalite", within which a 1.3m section ran 0.7 g gold/tonne. The "exhalite" is very likely a southwest continuation of the Scramble shear zone in the basalt country rock.  Combined linear magnetic anomalies and IP responses coincident with the Scramble Zone on the Scramble patented ground extend at least 150m onto the Scramble Property, beyond which power lines have to date prevented interpretation of geophysical responses across a 400m interval. Linear magnetic anomalies and coincident IP responses beyond this interval may represent the continuation of the anomalies coincident with the Scramble Zone.

One section in one of only two drill holes in this latter area ran 0.5 g gold/tonne over 1 m in a 2.4m core length logged as "felsic tuff'. This "felsic tuff' may be the continuation of the Scramble shear zone projected beneath the power lines.  A suggested plunge of the axis of gold values to the southwest at a shallow angle expressed by contours of grade-thickness values in longitudinal section on the Scramble Zone may extend into the Scramble Property at depth.

The demonstrated association of gold concentration at the Scramble Mine with a linear magnetic high and coincident IP response strongly suggests that such geophysical associations are prime targets. Other parallel linear magnetic anomalies have been identified on the Scramble Property, but not yet been tested for IP response or otherwise tested for gold mineralization.  A north trending fault identified on the Scramble Property close to its east side may displace any continuation of the Scramble Zone.

Conclusions

The Scramble Mine Trend can be traced from the Grey Eagle Mine in the south-west to the Black Sturgeon Mine in the north-east.  This structure has very good potential to host a number of deposits along the full length of its strike.  The Scramble property is immediately adjacent the Scramble Mine workings and will host the zone at depth and along strike.  The area within the Scramble Claim has seen limited exploration and therefore shows good promise.

name: Big Duck Lake
description: The 27 claim unit Big Duck Lake property covers over 4 kilometers of highly favourable geology and contains a total of 20 gold and base metal occurrences.
body:
Location and Access

The Big Duck Lake property consists of 27 claim units and is located just east of the Winston Lake Mine. It lies within the Wawa-Shebandowan trend 100 kilometers from the famous Hemlo gold camp, the latter which has over the past 30 years produced over 25 million ounces of gold.  Access to the west end of the property is via the Winston Lake Road a distance 20 kilometers north of Hwy 17. Access to the east part of the property is made by driving north on the Aguasabon Road for a distance 30 km north of the town of Terrace Bay and then by quad trail to the north end of Big Duck Lake.  The Winston Lake deposit, seven kilometers to the west of the property, produced 2.68 million tonnes of 1.05% Cu, 12.05% Zn, 31.37g/t Ag and 1.07g/t Au between 1988 and 1998.

Geology

The Big Duck Lake property is situated within the Big Duck Lake greenstone belt which forms part of the Archean Abitibi-Wawa-Shebandowan sub-province.  The claims are underlain by a thick sequence mafic massive and pillowed flows, minor clastic sediments, and iron formation. Coarse grained synvolcanic gabbroic sills are found throughout the property. These sills are at times difficult to distinguish from coarser grained mafic flows. Felsic quartz-feldspar porphyritic rocks (QFP) intrude the above units.  The main QFP body, which is situated along the north shore of Big Duck Lake has an apparent strike length of 3.5 km and a width of 400m. Associated with the main QFP are numerous QP and QFP sills which are found throughout the property. A distinctive fragmental unit comprised primarily of QFP fragments with subordinate mafic fragments in a mafic biotite rich matrix is situated along the northern contact of the main QFP body and the mafic volcanics. The origin of this fragmental is controversial, and has been described as either a re-worked lapilli tuff, tectonic breccia or a hydrothermal breccia associated with the porphyry complex.  The stratigraphy strikes 250° to 270° and dips 65° to 85° to the north.  Stratigraphic tops have been interpreted to be to the north.

The Big Duck Lake porphyry has been affected by four styles of alteration including sericitization, biotization, silicification and feldspathization. Disseminated pyrite is ubiquitous in all alteration styles. The heaviest concentration of pyrite (3-5 % on average) occurs within sericitically altered QFP adjacent to the fragmental unit.  The presence of these fragmental rocks and associated porphyry, occurrence of mineralization in the fragmental unit north of the porphyry biotite alteration, and associated Mo-Ba-Cu geochemistry of the gold mineralization are all characteristics shared by Big Duck Lake mineralization and the mineralized zones at Hemlo.

Recent Work

Quadro Resources completed a diamond drill program on the property in 2006, which consisted of 17 diamond drill holes totaling approx 3,500 meters. The drilling program intercepted Au mineralization in most drill holes, typically associated with low grade Cu mineralization (0.1-0.2% Cu), and anomalous Mo and Zn concentrations in pyrite-pyrrhotite bearing shear zone intervals within mafic volcanic rocks and deformed porphyry lenses (Feb 22, 2007 news release).  The drill holes were widely distributed over an approximate 3.5 km strike length along the Big Duck Lake shear zone system, and areas between and below the broader intercepts remain prospective, as well as extensions of geophysical targets which occur over known extensions and branches of the mineralized shear zones. The low grade, but broad intercepts may reflect up dip or lateral projections of larger mineralized areas which could be host to mineralization of economic grades, as is demonstrated by the Coco-Estelle prospect.

Quadro allowed the claims to lapse in 2010 and the property was promptly staked by the Author.  The property was subsequently optioned to Clear Gold Resources, which performed Mag/VLF and prospecting over a 4.6 km long grid along the north end of Big Duck Lake in 2012 and 2013.  Numerous gold and base metal occurrences were located and assayed.  Clear Gold’s shares were suspended from trading in September 2014 and the Company relinquished the property in December 2015.  The Author quickly re-captured a portion of the lapsed property that holds the bulk of the most promising showings.

Mineralization

Exploration for both gold and base metals in the Big Duck Lake area has been carried out intermittently since the discovery of a high grade zinc deposit (Zenith Mine) at Kenabec Lake in the late 1800's.  W.H. Collins passed through Big Duck Lake in 1905 during his exploration of the area for the Geological Survey of Canada.  His guide, Joe Fisher, returned to the area the following year to his hunting grounds and staked two claims with gold showings.  He sold the claims to T.K. Barnard, who later passed away.  Fisher then re-staked the claims and sold them to D. McCuaig of Schreiber in 1913 and the other to C. Sjolander and W. McKirdy of Nipigon in 1914.  The rich gold showings which came from these two claims resulted in 250 claims being staked there by the end of 1914. 

The majority of recent gold exploration in the Big Duck Lake area has focused on the Coco-Estelle Zone located west of Big Duck Lake, however, there are 20 gold and/or base metal occurrences within the property, many of which have seen little or no exploration.  A few of the more interesting showings on the property are discussed below:

Fisher Showing

The showing has three 15 meter deep shafts.  The host rock is a massive mafic rock but 25 meters to the north is an intrusive quartz-porphyry. Most of the rubble from the shafts are massive mafic material although a few blocks of rusty vein material consisting of carbonate, quartz, actinolite, 1-2% pyrite and traces of hematite were found. A historical grab sample of carbonate vein material with 1-2% pyrite assayed 5.7 g/t Au.  Sampling of an area near the #1 shaft in 2013 uncovered assays up to 7.3 g/t gold, 63.0 g/t silver and 0.22% zinc.  This part of the property, from the Fisher showing to Zone E (mentioned below) is a very strong exploration target for future work.

Fisher South

Prospecting south of the Fisher showing located an old pit.  Sampling here uncovered values up to 2.4 g/t gold and 7.5 g/t silver.  This area is quite likely the southern part of a wider zone that encompasses the Fisher showing the the north.

Zone E

A strongly mineralized zone, dubbed Zone E, was located between the Fisher and Sjolander-McKirdy deposits.  The 30 meter wide zone consists of intense shearing at the contact of a QFP and mafic volcanic.  The shearing is noted over 12 meters of volcanic rock and 18 meters of QFP with up to 15% disseminated pyrite in both rock types.  Assays returned values as high as 0.60 g/t gold and 3.6 g/t silver.  The zone lies 20 meters south of an intensely sheared QFP fragmental.  It appears this fragmental QFP strikes across the entire southern portion of the property, from the Fisher Showing in the west to the North Gold Zone in the east.  A similar fragmental unit in the area of the Nelson Pit on the adjacent patents has returned some very promising gold intercepts from previous drilling.

·       3.3 g/t Au over 3.2 meters within a larger zone grading 0.8 g/t Au over 24.7 meters

·       4.4 g/t Au over 5.5 meters

·       7.1 g/t Au over 3.2 meters

This fragmental shows remarkable similarities to the rocks at the Hemlo Deposit, and as such, is considered a high priority target.

North of Sjolander-McKirdy

A shaft on old patent TB 2116 is shown on geological map 2023 north of the Sjolander-McKirdy deposit.  There is no information available to the person(s) who dug this shaft or of the mineralized zone the shaft was put down on.  Reconnaissance prospecting discovered an unknown pit while looking for the shaft.  Sampling of the pit assayed 0.42% zinc.  Further prospecting in this area is warranted to try and locate the old shaft.

Dalsland Occurrence

The Dalsland showing contains appreciable amounts of sphalerite over a width of 6 meters.  The mineralization consists of traces of disseminated sphalerite in a bedded magnetite-rich chert. Thin (5 cm) garnetiferous beds and quartz-porphyritic tuffs are interbedded with this

exhalite. This exhalite-sediment package is bounded to the north by a coarse-grained gabbro and to the south by a mafic flow.  At the Dalsland showing there is an enrichment of sphalerite in the cross-cutting actinolite-quartz veins.  A historical drill hole (Canabel Syndicate, 1958) drilled 10 cm of 40% sphalerite at a depth of 117 meters.  Grab samples taken from the showing by Falconbridge in 1984 contained 5.1% zinc and 4.4 g/t silver in a actinolite-quartz vein with disseminated sphalerite (TBS 1576) and 0.5% zinc in a bedded chert with trace disseminated sphalerite (TBS 521). 

Recent sampling of the occurrence has returned the following results:

2012 sampling

·       N54011 - 5.58% Zn, 18.1 g/t Ag, 0.48% Cu

·       N54013 - 4.27% Zn, 6.4 g/t Ag

·       N54014 - 2.85% Zn, 7.9 g/t Ag

·       N54015 - 21.6 g/t Ag, 0.37% Zn, 0.37% Cu

·       N54016 - 3.46% Zn, 3.4 g/t Ag

2013 sampling

·       237051 - 1.56 g/t Au, 12.0 g/t Ag

·       237052 - 10.0 g/t Ag, 0.48% Zn, 0.26% Cu

·       237053 - 0.98% Zn

The Dalsland showing and the immediate area is very under-explored and represents a strong target for future exploration for its zinc potential.

Madson Showing

The Madson showing is a quartz-carbonate vein which has reported a 1.5 meter channel sample grading 3.7 g/t gold.  This vein, consisting of banded calcite, pyrite, sugary and glassy quartz, is reported to be similar to both the Sjolander-McKirdy and Fisher deposits.  The showing has not yet been relocated, but is suspected to be near L6+00W and 1+00N on the Clear Gold grid.  Three prominent VLF conductors lie in this area which require follow-up.

Madson East

While looking for the Madson showing, an unknown pit was located and sampled.  The sample ran 4.4 g/t silver and 0.41% zinc.  It is not clear if this zone represents an extension of the undiscovered Madson Occurrence or if it indicates a distinctly new mineralized horizon parallel to the Madson.

North Gold Zone

The North Gold Zone is within a mafic tuff which is finely bedded. A rusty zone with 2 to 4% disseminated pyrite occurs at the contact with a quartz-eyed (3-5%) QFP sill. Although there is a cross-cutting quartz vein, the gold is concentrated in this tuff.  Historical grab samples of the mineralization have assayed 6.32 g/t gold.  The geological setting is similar to the Nelson Pit Area (which is 400 m to the west) except the mineralization here appears to be hosted by mafic volcanics that are north of the main QFP but are south of a smaller QFP dyke. On the compilation map of Lewis, values of 3.8 g/t gold over 1.3 meters and 7.7 g/t gold over 1.5 meters are shown beside drill holes from this zone.  Recent sampling in 2012 have returned 11.6 g/t gold and 9.5 g/t silver from this zone.  The North Gold Zone is considered to be one of the best gold targets on the property, and requires further follow up work.

Stewart Pit

At the Stewart Pit showing there is a 3 meter deep pit into the side of the hill. This pit exposes a 1.5 meter wide rusty siliceous tuff with 3% to 10% disseminated pyrite and traces of sphalerite.

This mineralized zone, which trends 261° and dips 52° to the north, seems to be at the top of a stretched mafic pillow-pillow breccia sequence. The zone is overlain to the north by mafic pillows. Historic grab sampling of the mineralized tuff assayed 2350 ppm zinc and 281 ppb gold.  The showing was sampled during a property visit by Teck Corp in 2011 and assayed 1.23 g/t gold, 6.8 g/t silver and 0.33% zinc.

Gray Showing

The Gray showing occurs in a gossaned pillowed mafic flow containing quartz veining.  Previous sampling by MNDM geologists assayed up to 6.2 g/t gold.  Teck sampled this showing in 2011 which returned an assay of 0.44 g/t gold and 2.7 g/t silver.

Gray East

During their 2011 property visit, Teck located a rusty zone along strike and east of the Gray showing.  The sample ran 0.29 g/t gold and 5.8 g/t silver.  It would appear that the Gray, Gray East and Sock showing on the eastern property boundary all line up as a continuous zone of mineralization.  Sampling along the eastern property boundary in 2012, just north of the Sock Showing, returned a value of 2.45 g/t gold and 2.1 g/t silver.

Tri-Gold Trench #12

In 2011, Teck located two separate mineralized zones in Tri-Gold trench #12.  The northern zone ran 0.52 g/t gold, 15.3 g/t silver and 0.42% copper, while the southern zone assayed 0.58 g/t gold and 4.0 g/t silver.  These zones may be associated with the Tour Pit occurrence to the east and the Harvey Point occurrence to the west.

Tour Pit

Little is known about the Tour Pit showing.  It is suspected to be near the extreme southeastern part of the property south of the Sock Occurrence adjacent patent 2314.  A pit may have been sunk in a QFP sill that strikes across this section of the property.

Harvey Point Showing

The Harvey Point showing is located at the eastern end of Big Duck Lake. The showing consists of 4 trenches on the southern shore of the point. The host rock is a fine-grained massive mafic rock with QFP sills to the north and south of the showing. Pyrite occurs as disseminated and massive sulphides in a silicified and epidotized zone. Locally there is also hematite staining.  Historical sampling has returned 0.35 % copper and low values in gold.

East of Helin Shaft

The East of Helin Shaft lies on the north shore of Big Duck Lake where there is an old trench and shaft. The host rock is a QP but the material in the trench is so highly silicified that it is difficult to see any quartz phenocrysts. Disseminated pyrite (3-5% and locally 20%) and traces of chalcopyrite are associated with the alteration. The exposure in the area is quite poor and thus it was not possible to trace this zone along strike. Historical sampling has returned up to 0.62 g/t gold, 9.3 g/t silver and 0.07% copper.  The width of the silicified and pyritized zone is estimated to be at least 5 to 6 meters in the trench area.  Sampling in 2011 by Teck assayed 0.35 g/t gold, 3.5 g/t silver and 0.15% copper.

Tri-Gold Trench #9

Sampling in 2011 by Teck on Tri-Gold Trench #9 assayed 2.59 g/t gold and 6.8 g/t silver.  This mineralized zone appears to line up with the North Gold Zone.

Conclusion

The Big Duck Lake property is host to gold mineralization that occurs along the contact between mafic volcanics and a quartz-feldspar porphyry intrusion.  To date, over 40 separate gold occurrences have been identified in the area, including 20 showings within our new property.

The most notable occurrence in the area to date is the Coco-Estelle Zone, with a drill indicated resource of 53,700 tonnes grading 10.7 g/t Au.  This deposit is immediately south of our claims and is still held by Clear Gold Resources.  Gold mineralization is associated with disseminated Py (+/- Cpy, Sph) in zones of silicification, biotization and sericitization in the mafic volcanics, QFP and a distinctive fragmental unit located at or near the QFP-mafic volcanic contact. 

The mineralized setting has many similarities to the Hemlo deposit, including the association of gold mineralization with sericitic and potassically altered QFP, the presence of a distinctive mineralized fragmental unit at the QFP-mafic volcanic contact, and the presence of green mica, molybdenite and unconfirmed reports of barite associated with the altered QFP.  Given these similarities, a re-evaluation of the property with an emphasis on the potential of the Big Duck Lake porphyry as a gold bearing porphyry system is warranted.

In addition, potentially significant base metal occurrences are also found on the property, the most notable being the Dalsland Zinc Occurrence.  Some of these may be analogous with one or other of the Zenith or Pick Lake deposits on Inmet's Winston Lake property adjacent to the west.

name: Schreiber-Pyramid
description: An 8-unit claim block containing three parallel iron formations which carry high-grade gold, silver, zinc and copper.
body:
Location and Access

The Schreiber-Pyramid property consists of 8 claim units and is located in Priske Township, 4 km northeast of the town of Schreiber, Ontario.  Access is via 4-wheel-drive road north from the town to Big Duck Creek, and from there, via all-terrain vehicle to the property.

Geology

The property lies in the east-west trending Schreiber-White River greenstone belt of the Archean Abitibi-Wawa-Shebandowan Subprovince of the Superior Province of the Canadian Shield.  In the Schreiber area the belt is composed of generally east-west trending, north-facing, mafic metavolcanics with minor metasediments and mafic intrusive rocks.  The area within the 8 claim units is underlain by mafic metavolcanics interrupted by two northwesterly trending bands of chert-magnetite iron formation and clastic mafic metasediments. Metavolcanics and metasediments are cut by coarse-grained gabbroic dikes and quartz and/or feldspar-phyric felsic dikes/sills.

Previous Work

1934: Schreiber Pyramid Gold Mines Ltd. was incorporated, acquiring a 21 claim group.

1935: A small pilot mill was planned to treat reportedly high grade ore; camp buildings erected and a road built; No. 1 vein traced for 366 m with a number of visible gold showings. Other veins were located, stripped and trenched. The veins were bulk pit sampled and 1,700 kg of ore were tested.

1936: Stripping, trenching, diamond drilling performed; numerous buildings constructed; 5 ton bulk sampling mill erected and a 32 V electrical plant installed. At the end of the year, an adit was begun.

1937: An adit was driven into the No. 1 Vein. Kenecho Gold Mines took over in the summer. Three mineralized zones discovered in the southeast part of the property.  A total of 150 tons of ore was milled on site from the #1 Vein at an average grade of 17.6 g/t gold.  Operations were suspended in Nov. 1938.

1969: Zenmac Metal Mines Ltd. drilled 5 holes totalling 243 meters.  Best results are reported from a base metal showing located to the north of the Schreiber-Pyramid #1 Vein adit returning 4.6% Copper and 19.2% Zinc over 0.55 metres from the #2 Vein hosted within a chloritic shear zone.  The massive sulphides (po-py-cp-sph) intersected in the hole are hosted in a sheared mafic volcanic and are stratigraphically above a chert horizon exposed 25m to the east. It seems probable the base metals have been remobilized from the cherty metasediments during the emplacement of a coarse-grained gabbro which is in direct contact with the metasediments.

1985: Falconbridge Copper conducted HEM, VLF-EM, and mag surveys. Geological mapping, stripping, lithogeochemical surveys and sampling followed.  A one-foot chip sample of the rusty zone assayed 13.77% Zn and grab samples of massive sulphides yielded up to 31.0% Zn, 0.23% Cu and 0.74% Pb. Additionally, a grab sample from the #1 Vein located above the adit entrance assayed 45.2 g/t gold.

Resident Geologist personnel visited the site on three occasions (August of 1985, July 1, 1987, and August 5, 1992). Assay results ranged up to 0.92 oz/ton Au (10 inch chip sample) from the No. 1 vein. Assay results ranged up to 22.9% zinc, 17.5% copper and 4.47 oz/ton silver from a sulphide rich zone in the No. 2 Vein.

1989: Placer Dome conducted stripping and rock sampling on part of the Schreiber-Pyramid fault in the area of the No. 6 Vein.

1992: Tim Twomey conducted prospecting, stripping and sampling in the area as part of an OPAP grant. The property was also investigated for small scale mining potential.  Twomey discovered a 4 metre wide iron formation that returned a high of 0.156 oz/ton gold and a quartz vein located immediately to the east along a hydro right of way that assayed 0.337 oz/ton gold.

1995: The property was optioned by Twomey to RJK Explorations Ltd.  It is not known what work RJK did, if any.

1999: The property was staked and sampled by Brian Fowler under an OPAP Grant. Fowler received assays as high as 14.6% zinc, 19.6 g/t silver and 0.456 g/t gold from strong sphalerite mineralization within a narrow zone of intensely sheared mafic volcanics (Vein #2).  Fowler noted a strong linament heading east from the showing suggesting the shear zone continued in an easterly direction.  He recommended further prospecting along the easterly strike for a potential widening of the shear and additional mineralization.

2015: Fowler re-stakes the property due to a recent high grade gold discovery on his adjoining property to the north.

Property Mineralization

Vein #1

The #1 vein is exposed in two pits about 1,000 feet (300 m) apart. In both these pits the quartz vein contains pyrite, chalcopyrite and numerous showings of native gold. The vein is just under a foot in width, strikes N5°W and dips 50° to 55° W. It cuts across basic Keewatin flows to the south west of a mass of amphibolite, which outcrops in a band striking northwest. Although the two vein exposures are a considerable distance apart, they are believed to be the same structure because of their alignment, their attitude, and the fact that the vein in each exposure occurs on the east contact of a lamprophyre dike 2 feet (0.61 m) wide.   Twomey sampled Vein #1 for small scale mining purposes and outlined the following ore in situ:

·         Vein #1: 40 tonnes grading 1.01 ounce/ton

·         Vein #1 South: 52 tonnes grading 0.58 ounce/ton

·         Ore Bin: 15 tonnes grading 0.35 ounce/ton

Vein #2

The #2 vein is exposed about 500 feet (152 m) north east of the northerly exposure of No. 1 vein. It is 25 cm wide, strikes roughly N45°W and dips 45°NE. It is crossed by veinlets of calcite containing galena and sphalerite. Stripping has indicated a length of 250 feet (76 m). The vein occurs in andesite pillow lava on the north side of the amphibolite mentioned above. Between the amphibolite and the andesite there is a shear zone dipping 80°N which appear to have been developed along a narrow band of sediments. Trenching along this shear zone immediately south of the vein has disclosed mineralization 5 to 6 feet (1.5 to 1.8 m) wide consisting of massive bands of pyrite, pyrrhotite, chalcopyrite and sphalerite. It is reported that a considerable amount of native gold has been removed from the rusty outcrop in this shear zone. This vein (No. 2) was open cut to a depth of about 40 feet (12.2 m) for a distance of 50 feet (15.2 m). On surface the vein appeared strong, and good values were reported. At depth, however, the vein pinched out and work was suspended. Following this development, underground investigation of the No. 1 Vein was undertaken.

Vein #4

The #4 vein has not been well documented.  It was trenched in the 1930's and re-sampled by Twomey in 1992.  An assay of 0.03 ounce/ton gold was returned.

Powerline Occurrence (Tim Twomey)

Twomey discovered gold in 1992 while prospecting under OPAP grant assistance.  Schneiders (OGS Resident Geologist, 1993) described the Powerline occurrence as quartz veins associated with felsic intrusive dikes within mafic metavolcanic rocks. A quartz vein strikes 106° and dips 70°SW and has been traced for over 200 m along the power line. The vein averages 20 to 25 cm in width and displays a crack seal texture. The quartz vein occurs in contact with a pink hornblende syenite dike, which is commonly on the footwall contact of the vein. Several syenite dikes were observed in the area, up to 1 m in width. The quartz vein and syenite dikes are hosted by sheared and deformed pillowed mafic metavolcanic rocks. Extensional, sigmoidal, quartz filled gash veins are present within the metavolcanic host rocks. In one section, the main mineralized quartz vein displays a 20X flexure in strike. On the eastern end of the showing, approximately 300 m east of the main mineralized quartz vein, several narrow, mineralized quartz filled gash veins are exposed within syenite dikes.  A grab sample collected by the Resident Geologist's Program returned 0.337 oz/ton Au from the central section of the crack-seal quartz vein that contained minor pyrite and tourmaline.

Iron Formation Occurrence (Tim Twomey)

Twomey discovered a gold occurrence in iron formation that returned a high of 0.156 oz/ton gold.  The iron formation is hosted by fine-grained, pelitic, metasedimentary rocks or mudstone, as well as greywacke and minor conglomerate.  The iron formation is 3-4 meters in width and strikes 290° to 320° and dips 55° northeast.  Mafic intrusive rocks, mainly gabbro, intrude the metasedimentary rocks.  Gold mineralization is associated with secondary sulphides in crosscutting fractures within the iron formation, as well as sulphide replacements of the chert and magnetite layers.  Semi-massive pyrite is present over widths of up to 5 cm in association with cross fractures and replaced layers.  Pyrite preferentially replaces the chert layers in a “brick-work” type fashion.  The cross fractures strike 100° and are commonly associated with areas of jaspilitic iron formation.

Summary

The Schreiber Pyramid property contains a number of high grade precious and base metal occurrences.  The area has seen renewed interest in light of a significant discovery of high grade gold (53.7 g/t) on the adjacent claims.  There are multiple stacked iron formations throughout this area and within the property boundary that host potential discoveries of high-grade ore resources.  The iron formation labelled ‘Vein 2’ should be a high priority for exploration for a VMS deposit seated at depth.
